description:
This place is so nice and different and the location is great. Everything about it from the decor to the service to the food is amazing!

We were seated in the "kitchen" room where you can watch the chefs prepare everything. Our group was about 10 people and we shared several tapas plates and mains. Prices are on the higher side, but the quality of the food is definitely worth it. The wait staff was taking wonderful care of us, even though we arrived late and stayed even after the kitchen staff had cleaned up for the day.
Our favorites: oh so many! I loved the meatball appetizer, the crunchy potatos, the jamon spread (or was it chorizo???)... our clear favorite for entree was the pork chops. Getting soooo hungry as I write this!
Not so great in my opinion was the octopus dish. It was almost not seasoned at all and very soft. I like my octopus with more bite to it. Think al dente. 

Anyway, the concept is great, I will definitely be back.
author: Alexa W.

description:
What a lovely dinner Friday night at The Commissary following a show in the city. We sat at the kitchen counter in the back (best seats in the house) and were swiftly greeted by a lovely server and Chef Natalia, who guided many of our menu selections over the course of the evening. While the crowd was notably older (mostly 50+) and a bit on the "loud drunk" side, we really enjoyed our meal and service, so weren't flapped by it, other than a few knowing glances at one another.

YUM!
* Chorizo spread, grilled bread, pickled vegetables, frisée
* Cheese fritters, black truffle honey
* Spanish pork meatballs en salsa, pickled raisins, almonds
* Quinoa fritters, roasted autumn squash, charred leeks, romesco
* Strawberry panna cotta, granita, crisp


MEH
* Spanish octopus, avocado, za'atar, confit potato, olive tapenade (the texture of the octopus was a bit squishy)

Overall, a solid experience, all the more so since we live in Marin and dining in the Presidio means we're super close to home vs. getting stuck in the muck on a weekend. We will be back, though Coqueta remains our definite go-to if we're in the city and can snag a seat in their outdoor patio/bar area.

One final note, we had a 9pm seating and the kitchen closed by 10pm, so we did have to hurry through the end of our meal a bit (we were watching them clean for the latter part of our dining experience; our server comped us a glass of wine as a courtesy). Not a huge deal, but we were literally the last to leave when we departed shortly after -- just something to keep in mind.
author: Erin P.

description:
The food was good- not spectacular- but the service was S-L-O-W. We were essentially forgot with every course (including drinks) taking forever. Finally, we said something at dessert and they recognized their issue, gave us a free dessert and took 1 dessert off the bill.
Not rushing back but if I go back, I hope to get better service.
Also, waiter seemed to be pushing us to get more plates even though we said we were not that hungry. Just tacky.
author: Aztec G.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco since 2002 and I haven't really ventured out to the Presidio.  So I was excited to try the Commissary with my eating buddy.  The concept is Spanish-Californian and it certainly delivers.  

We were seated in the chef's counter right in front of the executive chef. It's absolutely the best seat in the house.  We ordered padron peppers, shrimp a la plancha, Spanish Octopus, dry-aged bone-in steak and the strawberry panna cotta.  Overall, the food was good.  The padron peppers were a bit overcooked. The shrimp and Spanish Octopus were excellent - highly recommended. The steak was HUGE and very, very tasty. I came here craving meat and mission accomplished.  The strawberry panna cotta was a great way to end the meal. 

Service was great and the ambiance was excellent.  It's pretty pricey - the above meal including a drink and tax and tip totaled about $110 per person.  I think this is definitely a good restaurant and would recommend it when you are in the area.
author: Andrew S.

description: Very elegant venues. Foods are very good and very good service. Their short rib mett in your mouth, so good. Their dishes good in quality but they give you very little.
author: Allen L.

description: Tucked away in the presidio and beautifully decorated, it can get busy but never too full. Our person (Khaled?) Was great at describing all the dishes and was so king, even coming out to say goodbye after we left the restaurant. Some dishes were better than others. The pork had too much fat for my tasting, but the cheese appetizers were amazing and so was the cookies with ice cream. It's especially nice to get away to a quiet destination without having to leave the city.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
A beautiful place, unique location, easy parking. Pricy menu but definitely worth it for those dishes that were indeed delicious. 

The Hibachi is a must-order, the Chicken with kale is very good and tender, and the Honey Custard desert is exquisite. 

The Patatas Braves with buttermilk weren't anything special, wouldn't order it again. Tasted like... well, potatoes with buttermilk. So expect just the flavor you imagined :)

The true disappointment was Branzino. It was very dry and cooked to the point that the spikes would poke your skin if you were to touch it! There was barely any meat we could salvage from it. Plus every piece was accompanied with a lot of bones. 

The real blow, however, came from the mistake made behind the bar that we weren't reimbursed for. The glass of sparkling brute came completely flat, and when my friend kindly asked to replace it, the server did so. However, we didn't get anything that would show that the restaurant was apologizing for it. We were charged for every single sip of that drink. 

I've worked in the restaurant business back in my day, and when you mess up, you show your appreciation by giving the customer a free glass or something of the sort.
author: Sasha F.

description:
Staff A+ Space A+ Food C-

we ate at the Commissary in Sept 2018 on a Thursday night, the place was dead (which I don't mind), the staff was fantastic couldn't have been nicer and the place/space is really cool. 
For apps we had the Octopus (B) and Padron peppers (A).  I had the Pork for the main course and the plate was cold and the meat was dry.  The other people at my table liked their food, so maybe my meal was the one off not-so-good plat of the evening.  but with a $213 bill for 3 people (4 glasses of wine) i was a little chaffed....  probally not going back.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Tucked away in the Presidio lies this little gem, The Commissary. The exterior and interior makes me feel like I'm enjoying a warm evening in the South.

Pros:
+ Servers are awesome - really friendly
+ Spacious and well-lit dining area - I can see the menu and my food!
+ Private dining room seats ~15 comfortably
+ Casual ambiance, didn't feel pretentious
+ Hidden from the bustle of the city
+ Unisex bathrooms are well maintained
+ Food was light and refreshing, not heavily sauced, ingredients seem top notch

Cons:
- Presidio scares me at night. Well, parks in general.

Recommendations:
[I forgot to take a picture of the prix fixe menu, so here's me trying my best to recall our private dinner on 10.05.2017]
+ Roast chicken with little potatoes, a green sauce, and I think arugula; 4/5
+ Chocolate soufflé; 5/5
+ Mixed greens with fruits; 5/5

The chocolate soufflé is an absolute must. Small, not overly sweet or rich, and just perfect. The salad starter was amazing! I can't tell if it's just me and my latest cravings for salads, but I loved the mixed greens with small cuts of...peaches or mango? The fruits and tangy dressing were both refreshing touches. As for the entree, I chose chicken just because it's more of a cooking challenge than steak. The skin was not overly fatty and had a beautiful light crisp crunch to it. Meat was lean but not overly dry. Could it be a little more moist? Sure, but I think they did really well in keeping it light and flavorful without killing it.

Beautiful space, great service, good food. Would definitely come back on my own dime!
author: Fanny W.

description:
Great staff, love the ambience in the restaurant, creative food!

I've only been here once but I loved their scallop dish of the night. The smoked octopus looked dynamite. Next time I hope to try their fried fish too. I had their potatoes which were really crispy and flavorful. Little heavy with the aioli but it always makes food tastier.

I hope to try one of their once a month five course nights with guest chefs!
author: Laura Y.

description:
Good service and food was decent. I think it would be great if they can tune down on the salt. I love salt but even that was too much for me. The menu is very unique. A lot of ingredients that I had never heard of. The BF and I had to google everything first before ordering haha. 

Service was top notch. Our server placed the wrong order for me and they handled it very well.
author: Gloria M.

description: Service was great. Wine selection was excellent as was the excellent bottle recommendation of a varietal I had never had. We went here for my dad's bday and they printed special menus wishing him Happy Birthday at the top. Amazing! The cheese bite appetizers are a must. As are the meatballs. The mains were good, not my jam though. My wife and dad both loved theirs, but the flavors just didn't hit for me perfectly, but still good. Portion size was a little light and the the bill was slightly heavy. Ambiance and window view was excellent. Would definitely go back and hope for a different main course that hits the mark. Worth trying if you haven't for sure.
author: Kevin S.

description: Great spot, really nice set up in the Presidio. Really liked our mains (T-bone steak to share was the highlight) as well as the salmon and biib lettuce salad. Cocktails were also very good especially the G&T. Would recommend for a more classy night out, always their menu changes frequently which is great, lots of variety.
author: Kyle S.

description: This was one of the most enjoyable meals I have ever had, and certainly the best meal I had while visiting SF. We were seated at the open kitchen, which was an enjoyable interactive experience. The food was excellent, as was the atmosphere. We enjoyed the patatas bravas, my boyfriend loved his octopus. We shared a delicious T-bone steak. In the end, we ordered 3 desserts to split- call us gluttons! The watermelon sorbet was divine! Plating was beautiful throughout the meal.
author: Michael J.

description:
Came here knowing chef Rogelio Garcia from Angeles Restaurant in Napa Valley, so we were excited to try out his food here. 

Everything was perfect from start to finish, the inviting lounge area, open kitchen settings, and more.... the gracious Sommelier, our server (from Australia or New Zealand) was super nice; and the nice GM too. 

The Chefs Series were amazing for the Tomato Dinner! You don't want to miss it! We were glad we came for the event with guest chefs:

-  Adam Ross of 1313Main Napa
- Sujan Sarkar of ROOH SF
- Joey Elenterio of former Chez TJ/Cadence 

Every dish was delicious, everything was fresh, so many dishes and amuse bouche, then extra desserts. 

Love their cocktails menu + wine list as well. I can't wait to come back. 

Wish I don't live 1.5 hours drive away, so I can visit more often. We will come back.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Another outstanding dining experience here under the direction of Executive Chef Eric Minnich. The dishes were a creative fusion of local ingredients designed with inspiration and prepared to perfection. The staff were friendly and efficient, especially our waiter John. We will definitely return as long as Chef Minnich is in residence.
author: Lisa Z.

description: Came here just for appetizers. The cheese fritters and salmon crudo were very good, but extremely small and quite expensive for what they were. The wine was good too but also quite expensive. Overall, it was good for appetizers but I don't know if I would come back given its price.
author: Kimberly T.

description: The Commissary is a hidden gem in the Presidio away from the beaten path. Celebrated our wedding anniversary here. Understated facade and interiors - which was appreciated as it was both elegant and comfortable, with really fresh, beautiful, unpretentious food. We sat at the open kitchen counter and enjoyed watching the chefs work their magic with fresh ingredients. Excellent service. We will be back.
author: Catarina K.

description:
Went here for the first time last week. As a big fan of Jardiniere, I was curious to see what Traci would do here. 
The space is open and inviting. The food was also very good. Not quite up to her potential in my opinion. Mostly average to above average, but maybe it was just high expectation. 

The biggest reason for the low rating was twofold:
1. The prices. Not worth it for the portions and the slightly above average taste. 
2.  The booze. Why is it that expensive restaurants give some chintzy pours? I ordered a martini and a glass of wine. Both with average ingredients but almost half of what you would expect in an average restaurant (and 1/3 of a Cheescake factory pour). Why is it that the more you pay, the less you get? It's Hendricks and Gin. Same ingredients.   Get it together people.
author: Paul E.

description: Extraordinary! A perfectly focused and satisfying meal from start to finish. Understated and courteous service, incredibly thought out menu. The best red snapper I had in a long time.
author: Camilla P.

description:
We went here for a dual birthday dinner and wow was it exceptional! First of all we were greeted with menus specially typed up for our friends saying happy birthday. Then before we could decide what to order the owner Traci came over to wish our friends happy birthday and shook all of our hands. 

The food was amazing. We tried essentially everything on the menu and there wasn't one thing we didn't like. The truffle burrata stands out for me, as well as the chicken and kale. 

Service was impeccable from our very friendly server, as well as the amazing somm Rachel! Rachel suggested an amazing pinot and overall the wine list was on point. 

While I think there are places with as good of food in the city for cheaper, the service here was exceptional. This was notable, especially whereas of late it feels as though service has taken a turn for the worst in SF. Coming back soon very soon!
author: Frank T.

description:
What a lovely fall evening the night we came here.  The Commissary has been restored beautifully inside, with the original flooring still intact and the incredible towering double hung windows  They just don't make them like that anymore.  Though the day was warm, it's rapidly cooling down this night, and all the windows have been left wide open with the diner at each table deciding to leave open or to close.  I closed mine right away, but ended up having to keep my coat on until the folks next to us left, because they left theirs open.  I would prefer the staff make the decision.  I certainly didn't want to have to negotiate with our neighbors.  So that was not a great beginning.  The waiter was charming, friendly, but not too.

We decided to start with a couple of their signature cocktails.  The bar was hopping, by the way.  I had an
 INFANTRY ROW
gin, cucumber, anise hyssop, lime, angostura, and a tarragon sprig.  Great cocktail, dry, refreshing and strong. 
T had a 
TWILIGHT
rye, amaro, east india solera, cynar, hellfire bitter.  I think I liked his better, except it had a very large (hand carved, according to our server) ice cube.  As the liquid level in the glass went down, it became almost impossible to drink without having your nose in the ice cube!

We noshed on a shared order of
 Patatas bravas, buttermilk alioli $9 4.5 stars:  So many ways to make this dish.  Here it was small yukon golds which had been baked and then smashed lightly and fried.  Would have liked a little more crunchiness, but the creamy buttery potatoes with the aioli and what I think was a romesco sauce underneath were our favorite of the night.

Entrees were
Bomba rice, mussels and clams, spanish chorizo, gamba $35, 3.5 stars:  OMG  Foamarama!  The entire top of the dish was foam, tasty foam, but way too much, too gimmicky, sauce would have been better.  The seafood was fresh and the rice and chorizo combined to make some great bites.  The one and only giant and beautiful shrimp was whole with head on, making it virtually impossible to eat.  I finally just had to pick it up and damn my manners.

Pork chop a la brasa, polenta, jimmy nardello peppers, $32, 3 stars:  Good quality ingredients, straightforward presentation, but as with the other entree, portions are small for the price.  The chop was well cooked, but just didn't wow us.

We each had a glass of the Tempranillo.  yummy, but at $14/glass, I think high.

So even with the little negatives, we enjoyed our evening, and I would certainly consider going back, especially with out of towners, because of the setting and the history.

Food: 30/40
Service 18/20
Atm/Intangibles:  16/20
Value: 15/20
Overall: 79/100
Almost 4 stars, but I'm not bumping up this time
author: Diane B.

description: This is a great place for a lively group!  The pear flatbread, cheese fritters (balls), and little gem salad with sunflower seeds and buttermilk were all great! For the kids, they have a nice grilled chicken and potatoes and cheese pizza. I enjoyed the churro with just the right amount of chocolate sauce. And, they will print messages on the menu if you are celebrating something.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I was so excited to try this restaurant and am a big Traci Des Jardin fan.  Family was visiting and I thought this would be a great and unique place to take them to on a Saturday evening.  That said, we were disappointed in our meal & service. The dining room is loud & we had to ask our server to nearly yell so we could hear him.  He was not very adept at answering our questions and seemed like maybe he was new and didn't know much about the preparations of the various dishes.  
I started with the Alegrias Para Ti cocktail, which was completely overpowered by the Mezcal (& I really like mezcal), knocking out all of the delicate flavors of the fruit juice, etc.  The Rioja was served in a high ball glass.  We were told this is how they serve wine in Spain but, in our experience is not accurate. They did however offer a stemmed glass once we asked about it.
All of the food descriptions sounded amazing with lots of delicate spices and flavors. Unfortunately most were over salted. The Iberico broth we ended up sending back because it was so salty (& they failed to take it off the bill until we pointed this out).  The octopus was cooked perfectly but again, was over salted.  The Catalan flat bread was tasty but unremarkable.  After reading the description, I was excited to try the meatballs but they were overpowered by garlic and the sauce was heavy.  We ended with the tuna tare tare which was delicious & the most redeeming dish of the evening.  We passed on dessert.
My most positive comment is the design of the space is gorgeous and cozy and both the food & drink presentations lovely. Parking is also remarkably easy.
Overall, it was just not as good as we were expecting with this calibur of chef and these prices.  Sadly, we won't be back.
author: Megan M.

description:
The Commissary is fantastic!.  We had our daughter''s wedding reception there and it was beyond exceptions.  The special events coordinator, Randalyn, was knowledgeable, quite helpful, flexible and very nice.
It is a very nice location with a relaxed atmosphere and an attentive service staff.  The food was excellent with a nice range of options.  
We felt like we owned the place and the unobtrusive staff took care of everything.  No bumps-only extremely happy people!
We would highly recommend this for a nice dinner or an event like ours.
author: Phillip M.

description: Having lived in Spain and knowing a thing or two about tapas, this restaurant is a sad excuse of a Spanish flavoured eatery. The food is so incredibly overpriced - $20 for five tiny tiny meatballs, dunked in cheap oil that gave me a stomach ache. The main was so small, I needed a magnifying glass to find it...not to mention that the fish was so overcooked, it tasted more like cardboard soaked in butter (another stomach ache). The vegetables were fried zucchini and onions...soggy like mashed potatoes mixed with water. What a disappointment.
author: Janos L.

description: Went to the Commissary last night for a dinner during my last week in SF. We were seated at the bar that surrounds the kitchen and loved being able to observe the chefs as they finished dishes. We ordered the cheese plate, patatas bravas, bacon-wrapped quail and short rib. I started out with one of their g&ts with pomegranate and then moved on to wine. Everything tasted great, but is a tad on the expensive side ($5-10 more than what you would think). It is clear that the quality of the food is exceptional, but definitely not a place for a weeknight dinner often. The waiters were super attentive and always refilling water and asking if we wanted more wine which was great. Will definitely come back when I want a fancier meal in the Presidio!
author: Zoe P.

description:
Thank you to the staff and the chefs for making my first experience at The Commissary amazing and very memorable.  Everything was delectable and the presentations were gorgeous!

Thank you for such a fun evening!
Lisa and Kevin Loughman
author: Lisa S.

description:
A group of girlfriends and I came here for dinner awhile back and since there were 6 of us, we covered a fair amount of the menu.  Things got off to a tenuous start; we weren't seated until almost 30 minutes after our reservation since the kitchen and restaurant were setting up for a private party that was going to be going on the same time at dinner. We were seated in the kitchen area, which was cool to watch, but dimly lit and hard to carry on a conversation. We asked our server how we should navigate the menu and she encouraged everyone to get their own larger entreé plate and an assortment of the smaller plates.  It seemed like a lot of food, but we went with her suggestion.  Here's what went down:

Appetizers:
- Bombas de queso with black truffle honey: Easily the best thing we had all night and the only thing I'd come back here for.  The little cheese bombs with truffle honey are bite sized, making eating these at a rapid pace entirely possible.

- Little gem lettuces, manchego, fried croutons, creamy pimentón
- Canary Islands pulpo, potatoes, olives, capers
- Patatas bravas, buttermilk alioli
- Sourdough pan de aceite, marinated olives, sheeps milk cheese
- Cheese plate
- Duck pâte on toast with marcona almonds

Entreés:
- Steak a la brasa, bacon roasted onions, spring peas, salsa española
- Roasted chicken, medjool date, marcona almond, liver toast
- Chickpea galeta, sugar snap peas, harissa yogurt
- Petrale sole, manila clams, chorizo, fennel, saffron

Desserts:
- Double chocolate-sea salt cookie and olive oil ice cream sandwich
- Fennel pollen churritos, sheep's milk crema, strawberries, chamomile

To start, we got way too much food.  The suggestion of everyone getting their own entreé was not a good one considering how many appetizer plates we got.  We ordered two steaks and two chickens and we were left with almost two whole plates of food by the time dinner was over.  The appetizers we had were delicious and we loved everything that we had.  The steak entreés were good, except that one of the steak dishes we had was better prepared than the other.  Desserts were a must order since we had all heard about the churros, and the olive ice cream sandwich seemed like a good thing too.  That being said, most of us had a hard time enjoying it since we were stuffed to the gills.  In any case, service obviously wasn't the best, but friendly nonetheless.

Finally, while this wasn't the restaurant's fault, my group of friends and I were laughing and having a fabulous time together and was asked to quiet down by another person sitting nearby.  It's unfortunate that this is going to be one of my lasting memories of this place since I love Traci Des Jardin's cooking so much, but I think I'll be visiting her other restaurants instead.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Right up there with the best Food I've had.

Astonishing array of flavours, textures and downright deliciousness.

Incredible setting, to me, it felt like a lovely English setting - I felt at home.

If you can, eat at the kitchen table, the theatre is worth it.

The service was passionate, genuine and cares about the food.

Can't really add anything else, excellent on all points. Well worth visiting.
author: John B.

description: We celebrated my graduation and passing my boards at The Commissary and I'm so glad we did. I've been in the industry for over 26 years and love the dining experience. This was one of the best I have had. We let our server John pick our appetizers and I'm so glad that we did. The patatas bravas and sourdough olive bread with goat cheese mousse were delicious. We then shared the tuna tartare, Spanish octopus, and little gems with stone fruit and buttermilk dressing. All three were so amazing that we couldn't stop talking about it. So much so that the woman next to us said she had to order the salad. Then we decided to share the 24 oz dry aged, bone- in steak with sherry cream. It was the most tender and mouth watering steak I have ever had. We ended with the chocolate churros with dulce mousse which was sent out with the a beautiful chocolate scripted "Congratulations" across the top of the plate. We sat at the chef's counter and watched them artfully prepare dish after dish. The staff was friendly and were happy to answer any questions that we had about the dishes. Charlie, one of the mangers, was kind enough to tell us about the chef and the history of the building that the restaurant was in. This added to our experience. I can't wait to come back. Dreaming about that steak.
author: Pamela C.

description: Way overpriced for what you get. 8/10 on food quality and drinks but not worth what they charge.
author: reza n.

description:
All I have to say is this was the most amazing culinary experience I have ever had. 

We went on the open kitchen series night, the service was great and not crowed at all. The food was beyond expectations. Each dish I had was better than the last. It slightly broke my heart that I will never have duck that good ever again.
author: Amy T.

description:
Spain Meets California in a Delicious Way

Chef Des Jardins restaurant is really rocking now.  A great, warm setting, killer cocktails and good in fog or in sun, Chef's food hits the spot. When I first went it was 4 stars.  Now it's hit 5 stars.  The food is bold, bright and crafted with artistry and love.  Careful... leave room for dessert too because that is surprisingly delicious!
author: FairReviews A.

description:
Sometimes there are those dishes that you just have to go back to a place for. Our last time at The Comissary, the temperature was a serious problem. It was just chilly in there. A nice place like this meant for dates for affluent people shouldn't have that type of cold. But we thought the fried bread was good enough to come back for.

Much to our dismay, when we came back, we got 2 breads, and both were overcooked. All the rest of the food was fairly off as well. The meat here just isn't well-cooked, how you'd expect a Top Chef-style restaurant to be. Tracy must not be very involved with this place anymore, as the food has fallen off. The most important thing for a restaurant of this caliber is to make sure each dish is stupendous and tasty. This place doesn't have that.

As a result, this place earned a lower review. It's still A-OK, but it's also expensive. It doesn't justify its cost. And therefore it's really 'Meh...I've experienced better.' We might give it one more try, but not unless we want to be cold and are just in the Presidio.
author: Aakash G.

description: Dinner at The Commissary, taken on the whole, is okay. The historic Presidio building its in earns a star. The service is worth a star. The food, while artfully prepared, interesting, unusual and tasty, warrants only a star because portions are ridiculously small and pricey. Four of us shared: canary islands pulpo (octopus), beet escabèche, mole @ $22 -- 4 tiny pieces of octopus (2 bites for each of us) and 3 tablespoons of diced beets; tagliatelle, english peas, parmesan  @ $30 -- about 2 cups of cooked pasta and peas; scallops, purple top turnips, passionfruit, squid ink, vadouvan (passion fruit puree) @ $34, 3 scallops and 3 pieces of grilled turnip; and short rib (1) a la brasa, potato, artichoke, bone marrow, leeks @$39. Satisfying, but far from filling. We're happy we had some wine, bread and cheeses at home beforehand. A one-time trip for us, and many diners, I suspect.
author: Steve K.

description: Excellent food and service. We were seated in the kitchen and were able to converse with the chefs and watch then create our meal. The food was creatively seasoned, the portions were just right, presentation was pleasing and we could not ask for better service.
author: Cary H.

description: Love love love the food. Great ambience, the staff is so friendly. The food again is amazing! There is always something new to try every time I go. Have never left disappointed. The pulpo, queso bombas, and the bread are so delicious to start of with. The food is not just delicious it is an art, complete master piece, I love how the food is presented and definitely how it tastes. You can't go bad with the Commissary.
author: Karina M.

description:
Fan"fricking"tastic.... The food, service, ambiance ....
Will definitely return and suggest to others
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Wanting to get out of the normal restaurant scene in SF but not wanting to cross the bridge or go south, I found myself at The Commissary swept back to simpler times. This former mess hall built in 1895 greets you with its southern-style front porch then warms your heart with its casual California menu filled with items your mom likely made, but just kicked up a notch. For example, you'll find your mom's chicken, but with dates, almonds, and frisee. And that other meat dish you see? It's the bacon wrapped guinea hen breast with brussels, trumpets, and cumin rice. Definitely something I cannot cook at home!

The Commissary is a great escape from the city by being tucked into the Presidio right off Lombard. This makes it a great place to take folks who don't want to be overwhelmed by the city, especially because parking is quick and easy to find and the menu isn't pretentious. With a full bar, all are welcome in this work-casual restaurant that is also great for dining before special events. I saw lots of khaki's along side black-tie patrons and it all seemed to work!
author: Regina D.

description:
So we went for Valentine's Day, which was probably a bad idea. We didn't realize there was going to be a prix fixe 5-course menu of $110/person. Out of the 5 courses, I only really liked 2 dishes: the watercress and potato soup, and the suckling pig tortellini (the latter was amazing!!!!).

Everything else was pretty meh. We got the caviar tasting, which was good except it was atop a tater tot-like thing which was too much tater. It would be better on a blini. The octopus needed more of a char. It was a bit slimey. And the beef with the polenta was super fatty... There was like a feeling of a layer of grease on my tongue every time I took a bite. I just didn't like that the chef put such a fatty meat on top such rich polenta. I actually avoided the polenta, which I typically like, and tried to take a bite of meat with the brocolinni to balance things out. There really was a need for more texture on this plate.

What I did love, however, was the service and the wine pairing. The wines were spot on! The guys who served us really knew their thing, so kudos to them! Unfortunately, we decided this is not a do-over. Too pricey for what you get.
author: Mariecar M.

description: With a name like Commissary I was expecting American food but was pleasantly surprised with the Spanish fare. It was delicious! My husband and I shared most of our dishes - I'd recommend the cheese fritters, the smashed potatoes, the flatbread and the short rib was really delicious. We had wonderful service - very knowledgeable about the menu and made excellent recommendations. Highly recommend and can't wait to go back!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Good food - not great; warm ambiance, cool/snooty host and servers. Semi-interesting wine list and creative food. But overall an extremely disappointing meal. I've been SF for three days, this is the worst dining experience I've had with my family since we've arrived. We had outstanding food at Hog Island, stunning mussels at Original Joe's in North Beach, very delicious bites at BAR BOCCE in Sausalito - great food and wonderful service at the Balboa Cafe in Mill Valley and tons of yummy dishes at M.Y. China. 

I'm from LA and our family loves good food! SF has delivered ... but this is an example of OVERRATED! The serving staff is cool and on the slow side. Portions are tiny and I mean tiny. I'm a 125 pound female and I left the restaurant hungry after an appetizer - main course and dessert.  

Finally, it is an incredibly OVERPRICED restaurant. We are a family of foodies, we eat out in LA often and we've had lovely meals in San Francisco, but between attitude and cost - I'd never-ever come back and I'd never recommend it.
author: Laura G.

description:
Nice to have a place in the Presidio with interesting food. Great service- they offfered is a place in kitchen cuz we had no reservations. Only downside it was really smokey.
   We ordered fish which was crispy and delicious and while. Red snapper. Not too many sides so was a little disappointed there. People around us ordered very interesting dishes and it was nice to compare. My friend and i shared the fish- enough for two.
   Dessert was a very bland choc soufflé but the hard sauce was good... lavender infused. We sat at the dessert station so we watched them make all kinds of goodies.
    Id come back.
author: Kim C.

description: Good food with pretty presentation. Great atmosphere in the Presidio building. Sitting at the counter provided entertainment - so it seemed since we were at a nearby table and kept looking over. Food was priced higher than we were expecting, but this is San Francisco after all. All the entrees and dishes were promoted as "shareable" - only for me, myself, and I. Portions were rather small for others to dig in, unless you just wanted a bite. We left mostly satiated but one or two of us needed an In-and-Out run after.
author: Lainey S.

description: The place is pretty good... great service and beautiful setting
author: Isra N.

description: UNDERRATED! Definitely sit around the kitchen bar. The food is absolutely top notch. I had the braised short rib and sampled the mushroom raviolo. The best I have ever had. For the life of me I don't understand why this place isn't packed daily.
author: Ken S.

description: We had our company party here and I thought they did a great job. The bartender made me an off the menu shrub made from fresh squeezed juices. The octopus first course was amazing. The potatoes, Brussel sprouts, and cauliflower polenta were delicious. My steak was perfectly cooked. Had a great time and great service.
author: Ken A.

description: Servers were super friendly and the food was amazing. The mushroom risotto and lobster tail were delicious. 10/10 would recommend. Definitely coming back!
author: Bryan F.

description: Such a disappointing experience!  Went for a birthday dinner for 5 of us- $600 and nothing had any taste.  Our waiter was new and couldn't answer many questions.   A beautiful space- I was expecting the food to match.  Descriptions sounded great but taste just wasn't there.
author: Catherine K.

description:
The food was alright.  The appetizers of a cheese plate and some other notables such as salmon tar tar on a chip and ribeye on toast.

The iceberg lettuce salad was drenched in dressing definitely could have done with less.  The entree of salmon on top of brussel sprouts was tasty yet small.  The berry yogurt was good as well.
author: Kent H.

description:
My friends and I had a recent dinner club at The Commissary and had a great experience.  Dining in the Presidio is a pretty amazing thing and The Commissary did it right.  The wait staff was nice and super helpful in guiding us on what to get to drink and eat.

We all started with a number of various cocktails and wine.  I had the Official and it had a a strong jalapeno taste which I enjoyed.  From there we shared a bunch of things including the peppers, bravas, albondigas, burrata, pulpo.  I had the pork chop as my main entree and it was really good.  For dessert we shared the ice cream sandwich, fritters and sorbet.

Good place to dine with a big group of friends.
author: Blake B.

description: First time eating here was for Easter brunch, and though the offerings were rather atraditional they were delicious nonetheless and ultimately much-preferred. I'll be back to try out their dinner menu, especially since the incredible cheese fritters with truffle honey are served then, too! Service was lovely, by the way -- kudos to a kind and well-trained staff.
author: Kim S.

description: Extremely pleased with experience.  Everything we had, including bread, initial small plates, entree and dessert were really outstanding and delicious.  The staff were so nice and friendly.  Our male waiter, Kelly, could not have been better, and was so friendly and nice.  Would like to go back for sure.
author: Stan B.

description: Solid 4 stars for this restaurant. Came here for a Birthday celebration. Booked an early dinner so parking was not a problem. Walked in and hostess (key) was very nice and welcoming. Ordered the cheese fritters, squid, and the potatoes for appetizers. Portions are not big so you might have to place two orders. Our entrees were Steak, Fish, Paella, and the chicken. Entrees portions were bigger than appetizers. All our dishes were delicious. Service was excellent and don't forget to order dessert. Their dessert was awesome too. Definitely recommend.
author: Joe M.

description:
We booked reservations almost a month in advance to celebrate a special occasion. I started having second thoughts when a few friends told me this place was only ok and they wouldn't go back. Then, one day before our reservation, the restaurant called me to tell me that they could no longer seat us properly because they had a private party that night. Huh?!  Really?!  

I have never had that happen.  We managed to find another spot but at the last minute you don't get the same options as when you are a month in advance. 

So, be warned - this place is not high integrity.  I think they just thought they had a better deal and could get away with mistreating people along the way. Fellow Yelpers beware!
author: Karen P.

description:
For a restaurant of this price point, the service should be a lot better. I came here with a party of 5 on a Saturday night. The place was busy, but not exceedingly so. We had a reservation at 8:45pm, but were not seated until after 9pm, which was weird because there appeared to be several open tables in the main dining room. While we waited, we ordered drinks from the bar. We were told to wait in the seating area and the drinks would be delivered to us. We obliged. When we were seated 20 minutes later, we still didn't have our drinks. 

We were seated in a private dining room with four or five tables in it. The menu was impressive and most everything seemed appetizing, which you'd expect, especially with Chef Tracy Des Jardins elite reputation behind it. But here's another strike against them: We were informed immediately they were out of their signature bread, and this is the way it was explained to us. "We have other bread, but it's not as good. We'll bring that to you. The good bread--the bread people come here for...we're out of that." I get it, sometimes these things happen. But they shouldn't happen on a Saturday night. We soon learned there were at least two other menu items they were out of as well. Boo. 

The food we did order was very good...everything except for the mushrooms and onions. That could very well just be my palate though. Overall, the food was solid, but you do pay for it. I don't actually mind the price point, as you won't do much better at similar restaurants in San Francisco. Where you can do better is the service. The table next to us seemed to be having a similar experience, as members of their party took to getting up to refill their own water glasses across the room. 

If service is important to you, this place may have more kinks than you're willing to deal with. Hopefully they get them worked out soon.
author: Brian K.

description: We rented out The Commissary for our wedding reception and we could not have asked for a better evening! We worked closely with Randalyn, the event coordinator, and found her to be very responsive and helpful. She brings a lot of experience to the table and was a great partner to have throughout the planning process. The restaurant is beautiful, the staff are incredibly nice, and the food is absolutely delicious. We would highly recommend this restaurant for a wedding reception, and of course for dinner any night of the week!
author: Craig S.

description:
I've had a really mediocre meal here, and another amazing experience here.

The underwhelming: Brunch. I came here for Sunday brunch for mother's day. My sister and I ordered quiches, and they both came out cold. There wasn't much of a selection, service was slow despite it not being very busy, and food just seemed overpriced. Off the grid was happening outside, and you could tell everyone was kind of looking outside wishing they were eating outside instead.

THAT BEING SAID, I had a great time when I came for dinner. My friend and I sat in the back room on the bar-ish area where we could see all the food being prepared. There was so much going on, so you could see how much effort is being put into your meal. The waiter was incredibly attentive and charming - wish I could remember his name. My friend accidentally spilled water on her food, and they insisted on preparing another dish for her even though she had already made a decent dent in her meal! We ordered dessert, which was my favourite part!

Even if you don't come for food, I highly recommend coming for drinks. We ordered sangria which was perfect for a summer day (ok, we went in the winter, but it was still good).

Finally, there's SO MUCH PARKING - yay! And even if you don't park, there's the free PresidiGo shuttle you can take from downtown / san francisco proper that runs until 9 30 pm.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Came here for a dinner date with my gf and had a fantastic time! To start I was running very late (as always) for our reservation time but the hostess accommodated my gf and I the moment we arrived which was awesome. We got a seat right by the kitchen which made the experience even more enjoyable as we got to see all the food being prepped right in front of us. 

Our waiter was very attentive throughout the night. Always had a smile on his face which I appreciated.The service here from start to finish was outstanding!

Now for the food. We started out with bombas de queso with black truffle honey. They were sooooo good. Rich in flavor with a generous amount of truffle honey as well. 
Next we got the canary island pulpo. I always try to get octopus if it's on a restaurant menu and this one was definitely one of the best I have had. Meat was tender and juicy. The presentation of the plate was also great, the smoking technique gave it a unique flavor.
For my entree I got the steak a la brasa with bone marrow. Steak was cooked perfectly medium. The bone marrow was the perfect compliment (as always) to a great steak. The potato was very fluffy and complimented the dish as well, highly recommend this entree or the sea bass my gf got.
Lastly, we ended with the huckleberry fritters for dessert. I have never had huckleberries before but I am a big fan now! The squash crema seemed so odd at first but paired perfectly flavor wise.

Overall I had a great experience here and will definitely be bringing my friends and family when they come to visit. Highly recommend this place!
author: Josue V.

description:
Sometimes I put off places because it's too far from me and I just don't want to get myself over there.  The Commissary was one of those places. The Presidio is just too damn far and there's no reliable public transit that way from the Castro, but one Friday night, I was feeling like I wanted to complete some more items from the 7x7 list since I felt like I was behind for whatever reason. 

I ordered the roasted chicken (dish on the 7x7 list) and it was delicious. I had heard bad things about it through reading reviews, but it was juicy, and the favorite part of me was the pairing with dates and these delicious almonds.  The little toast with some chicken liver mousse? Amazing couple of bites.  I thought I was going to get some lame dish, but it was definitely list worthy - though far from most restaurants in SF.  I also got the seasonable sorbet (quince) and I was really able to experience the apple-pear tasting fruit.  It was definitely delicious. A glass of white sangria rounded out my experience. The bar was a great place to sit, no reservations needed and a great space to talk to strangers. 

Protip: get the roasted chicken. It's a pretty decent sized portion of delicious chicken.
author: Nina Y.

description:
It is hard for me to understand anything less than 5 stars if our experience last night is typical.  From greeting to moving tables to presentation to portions to ambiance and top-flight quality of every dish, this was a hit.  Special Kudos to Kelly (server) and Aaron (manager) for making this a fantastic evening.
Two suggestions - sit in the kitchen, preferably at the chefs bar and watch (interact) the show. Fun and informative.  At least try both the chocolate empanadas and cinnamon ice cream sandwich.  Killer!
author: Sammy P.

description: The food and drinks were equally delicious as well as interesting. Some new flavors mixed with old that just worked extremely well alongside new ideas that also shone through and are worth a revisit! The location is perfect as is the decor of the old building itself.
author: Gregory F.

description: My experience here was nothing less than amazing. From the friendly service to the small details in the food. I really recommend this place to anybody! Food was amazing I swear ! The short ribs were to die for!
author: D B.

description:
I experienced superb wait and wine service from Ryan and staff. Therefore, I am awarding The Commissary a 4th star.

The restaurant has a super location (on the Presidio parade grounds, very close to the Walt Disney museum) and ambiance. The place is huge, so capacity and parking on a Saturday night during Fleet Week was not a problem. 

The Commissary is a good place for single diners who want to sit at the bar or by the kitchen. There's lots to see, do, and discuss. Also, this is a great place for a date, the lights are low and the noise is compatible with conversation.

I found the cuisine to be sophisticated and delicious. Not at all your normal fare.

I recommend:
* Pasenau Priorat Ceps Nous 2010, a Spanish/Catalan blend of Garnacha, Mazuelo, Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot (dry, rich flavor, nice nose, and smooth finish)
* Albondigas (meatballs) appetizer
* New York Steak, broccoli rabe (leafy green broccoli rabe has 6- to 9-inch stalks and scattered clusters of tiny broccoli-like buds), potato-idiazabal gratin (Spanish goat cheese), mojo verde (a blend of garlic, bell peppers, olive oil, vinegar, cumin seed and salt)
* Stone Valley Farms pork with eggplant, escalivada (smoky grilled veges) and black coco beans
* Fried Brussels sprouts with chorizo
* Dessert: 
     Torrijas with huckleberries, bay leaf ice cream, and marcona almonds
     Ricotta cheesecake, figs, burnt honey

Enjoy!
author: Reyn J.

description: Really high quality food and service. Had the pork tenderloin, it was amazing! Everything on the plate needed to be there. On top of that, the dessert was perfect, not too sweet. I really had to resist ordering a second. I will definitely return. The location alone is unique enough to encourage a trip. We walked into the Presidio for our reservations at The Commissary and were able to see many features of this historic property. The whole experience was memorable.
author: BK T.

description: Great food and service. Perfect place to spend our Anniversary!! They had Pre-printed anniversary menus, glasses o Cava waiting for us and a seat in front of the kitchen. Yum!
author: Bert J.

description: Delicious branzino with very few bones. Very good octopus. The olive oil bread is amazing. The ice cream sandwich was good too.
author: Luke F.

description:
I can understand why people would like this place, but it just didn't fit the bill for me. I needed the waitress to explain the menu, firstly, that's never a good thing in my book. Stylistically it fit the bill, but it made it no less confusing for me.
The octopus was small and rather disappointing, as was the steak a la brasa. In truth, the only food I found to suit my tastes was the mashed potatoes that came with the steak. Even the herbal tea fell a little bit short of my standards. And all this for prices that are far too high.
That's not to say this place doesn't have its strengths. The service is quick, the waiters are patient and friendly, and there was virtually no line. The place is clean, atmospheric, and accessible for anyone in the Marina. Again, I can understand why people would and do enjoy the food in this establishment. But for me, I'll give it a pass.
author: Guide S.

description: We love The Commissary and it has become one of our favorite dining spots! Tessa, one of the GM's and her staff always take great care of us. The space is beautiful, it never feels overly crowded or loud and the food is amazing! Inventive cocktails, fresh, beautifully prepared food and wonderful desserts make for a lovely evening. Last time I had the whole branzino which was a gorgeous presentation and so delicious! Also, don't miss the octopus which is one of their signature dishes and so incredible! Driving into the Presidio is always a treat and parking is always a breeze. What's not to love!
author: Scott C.

description: Dad loved the fish, but there's not much else to rave about. Food was mediocre, my seafood/Bamba rice dish was under seasoned and undercooked. Friendly but Extremely slow service, which usually wouldn't bother me, but when it takes 20 mins for drinks at a 3 top and nearly an hour for appetizers, that's a bit too much for the price point. We came for a birthday dinner and I nearly left before my "surprise" dessert, which mom had to ask for a second time. Dessert was delicious. But overall, not worth the wait.
author: Natalie R.

description:
The Commissary is housed in a remodeled barrack in the Presidio which I must admit is pretty cool. When our maître d' led us to our seats, she got very giddy because as she put it, "You are getting my favorite seats in the house." I love "chef's tables" and ended up having a great time watching the kitchen. The Spanish-influenced menu had some hits and misses. The pulpo was complex and delicious while the stone fruit salad was a little uninspiring. For the big plates, the roasted chicken was huge in size but not in flavor. The petrale sole was more interesting. There was a long wait between the first and second courses probably due to some kitchen hiccups. They gave us a free order of bombas without prompting. That was a nice gesture especially when those little round suckers were so tasty!

P.S. Getting to the Presidio to dinner isn't particularly easy unless you live close by. But the Presidio is the best in gorgeous weather like today's. A short stroll before dinner was absolutely awesome.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Came here with my girlfriend, mother and aunt. Seemed like a cute, low key place for everyone to meet for the first time, plus chef Tracy De Jardines?! Sounds like a winner! Mistake. Service was SO slow- on a Monday night. Cocktails & food were mediocre. I was so upset that they falsely advertised their "open kitchen". There is a HUGE wall separating the main dining room from the beautiful kitchen. When we asked to be moved into the kitchen area we were told only parties of 2 or 6 can be seated there. 

We arrived at 6:30 and did not finish dinner & dessert until 9:30 due to the slow service. The host (maybe restaurant manager?) tried to make up for this by taking 2 cocktails off our bill (out of 8). He also brought us all complimentary glasses of sherry and an olive oil cookie sandwich to share. Unfortunately, that was all in vain. All cocktails should have been comped at the very least- you can keep the sherry. 

Overall, the experience was awful and I will not be returning.

One star for being flexible with our reservation as we were running about 15 minutes late and one star for the olive oil ice cream cookie sandwich.
author: Mandy W.

description: I love the cocktails and the atmosphere is pretty nice but I wish they would  enhance the menu. The appetizers are boring and the main courses have been the same for ever. At least offer a yummy burger so people can sit at the bar with some fries and a cheeseburger.
author: Ann W.

description:
The pluses:
Beautiful space with grand open kitchen in a 130 year old brick military building. They certainly had a good architect.
Parking super easy....like right in front.
Waiter was funny and approachable.
Did I mention the cuisine?...guess not because that one's not much of a plus!

Minuses:
Expensive
Teeny tapas with grand prices
Slow service actually helped me as I was held up at a meeting and arrived 90 minutes late.Nobody in our party of 10 had ordered after 90 minutes! So bravo to that.
Fussiest menu I've ever seen in, like, the world.
I am not an adventurous diner. I would NEVER consider a prix fixe restaurant where they ordered for you. The menu, while some may think it is cutting edge, is not for me. 

OK, so I'll have a Coke, they've got a full bar. 'Oh, sorry mister, we don't have those kind of unhealthy things here'  WTF? 
As for the chicken. OK, but worth half the price. The patatas bravas, decent but also such a tiny portion it wasn't worth it.
In summary, the food could be good,and tries. If you are up for an expensive snack The Commissary could be an option.
author: Andreas M.

description:
Opening the door here for the first time gave me two first impressions:

1. This is really a historic military installation and it feels like a 'lived-in' space - you can close your eyes and imagine military personnel eating here a century ago.  This is particularly augmented by the historic photographs lining the walls of black-and-white windows into what the Presidio was way back when.
2. Just before prime lunch time, the place was about 10% full when we walked in (~11:45AM).  When we walked out (1PM), it was about 33% full with all the outdoor seating taken.  I wish we had the option to sit outside, but apparently every table in the place was reserved (by ghosts?).  

The food here was really good, and it was obvious the chefs have a good amount of skill.  My appetizer was the pâté de cerdo, pickled onion, whole grain mustard, grilled bread (pictured), and I got the mushroom escabeche montadito with arugula as my main course (also pictured).  I also tried a bit of the pan roasted chicken breast, artichoke, kale, and chorizo vinagreta that was also ordered at the table.  Every dish was nicely plated and had just enough to leave you sated (but probably still have enough room for a dessert).  

A few cons made it fall short of a solid 4*:
- comparing the two things I got, the value didn't match up - the pate appetizer was $10 and the main was $13, but the main had significantly more food on the plate (I didn't finish it - more on this next)
- my main (mushoom escabeche montadito - good luck pronouncing that right the first time) had good flavor and the mushrooms were cooked perfectly, but it got monotonous and was a bit rich/heavy halfway through the 2nd half of the open-faced sandwich.  Whatever cream-cheese-like spread they used, I didn't want to keep eating it the whole way through.  
- the kale in the chicken dish was overcooked and soggy
- there was also a burger ordered at the table, which was cooked to the wrong side of medium

Overall I enjoyed the food but I probably wouldn't come here again due to the price.  The Presidi-tax strikes again!

(3.5 stars)
author: Ben K.

description: This place is fantastic. One of my favorite spots in SF...and I hate driving around in SF. Everything is always unique here, and the chefs are amazing. I'm not going to divulge any info. Check it out yourself and see. No restaurant is perfect, it's a human run establishment, so disregard all the negative reviews and experience it for yourself.
author: E H.

description: The Brazo del Mar cocktail was smoky and unique, olive oil bread with sheep cheese and olives was awesome, Bombas de queso were great, and the cod and pork were also tasty. The beet gratin and the potatoes in the octopus salad were our least favorite,but overall it was a good meal with attentive service.
author: Lori G.

description:
The best product from this restaurant was outsource.  Danishes are killer- not original.  Sangria is good (But so is mine). 

I paid $18 for a seasoned chicken strip on a stale bun (they call it 'fried chicken sandwich' on brunch menu).  Some of my friends had plates that sat under heat lamps for 10+ minutes.  

This restaurant exists because of a celebrity personality. Nothing to write home about.
author: Todd N.

description: We returned a second time for our son's one-year birthday. Sat inside this time, and had all different dishes. Once again, the service was amazing (the friendliest we've found in the city), and all of the food was excellent. This is definitely our new 'go to' restaurant when spending a day in the city.
author: Brendan M.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant in SF. I know that's a big statement, and I need to return to find out if it is consistently great. But we had a nearly perfect experience that was unexpected. 

Our group was all locals (well-travel and well-dined) plus a visitor from Italy. The number in our reservation changed a couple of times and each time we called we were treated with courtesy. 

When my husband and I arrived we were impressed with the feel and decor. It was both leanly elegant and also respectful of the location's history.  We were a little early and watched our table being set; we noticed the private dining room and asked if that might be available. It was! 

Our group made full use of the interesting menu, selecting and sharing 2 tapas, a salad and 2 vegetable sides. The flavors and textures were all delicious. Particularly interesting and flavorful was a mole bone marrow dish - but not everyone in our group was willing to try it. 

Next came the mains. Our vegetarian and one meat lover order the chickpea pancake entree. Both enjoyed it. The chicken entree on any menu is a good test of a chef's creativity and this was a home run, served with figs and liver pate on toast. I'm not sure what entrees were further away from me, but everyone reported being happy and impressed with the food. 

Next time I go to Commissary I will sit in the room with the kitchen.  This room had a whole different vibe that I will enjoy exploring with a smaller group.
author: LH M.

description: The food and service were really good. Not a huge fan of their cocktails, but otherwise nice place to have dinner
author: Erin G.

description:
Follow up review - just to make sure:    A "meal" is the sum of many things.  Food, atmosphere, service, wine, etc, etc ... right down to a free place to park.  Again, a fantastic meal in all respects.  

We sit at the kitchen bar where, because it is Fed land, the CA separation of patrons from prepares is not required.  So we can enjoy observing the staff clicking like a control tower - all the care and details ... while getting a preview of what looks good on the changing menu - all while having a pre-dinner cocktail.   It helps that the exec chief was perusing each plate before the efficient and knowledgeable waitstaff whisks it away.  He oversees other restaurants, but it is hoped his constant coaching and correcting will insure we have an equally good meal every time we return.
author: Rod S.

description:
I was excited to try this restaurant since the day it's open. The location is amazing with parking right out front. The interior was open and fairly cold feeling. There are tables in the bar and dinning area, which also has a huge chef's counter.

The olives were delicious, but hard to screw up. The calabaza croquettes had a subtle orange favor but were nothing special. The kale salad was the best dish of everything we ordered, which says a lot! The chicken is supposed to be one of their signature dishes and it was ok, but not great.

Overall I was sadly disappointed by the food and ambiance and would not go back.
author: Emily C.

description:
Wow!
This place it out of this world fantastic!!!
Elevated Spanish influenced Californian cuisine  with a large selection of fantastic wines at a wide array of prices.
Award-winning chef Traci Des Jardins--- understandably so!!
Located in the heart of the presidio... you can totally walk to the bay & view The Golden Gate Bridge from here! (super romantic) & located in a former mess hall that has been transformed into a comfortable modern & elegant restaurant.
Servers were excellent, knowledgeable, & available if needed.
The food was like I said, out of this world! I dined with a party of 6 so we tried most of the menu & everyone was very pleased!

Items we tried & loved (that I can remember)
- Salt cod fritters, lemon aioli
- calabaza croquettas, charred orange aioli
- Quesos: st. george, caña de oveja, txiki, membrillo
- Crispy new potatoes, salsa brava
- little gem salad, manchego, cured anchovy, fried bread
- octopus, potatoes, olives, lemon--- I have since had better octopus but it was decent
- roast cuttlefish, arroz verde, squid ink
- jamon wrapped trout, trumpet mushrooms, sherry, tarragon


We had wine that are server recommended after letting me sample a few & his suggestions were fantastic! We will definitely be going back here again for a special occasion meal!
author: Ashley G.

description:
My husband, myself, and a good friend had dinner here and all I can say is...it was REMAKABLE! 
One of the best dinners I've had in my entire life! 
Everything about it was perfect.
author: Casey H.

description:
What a random place in the middle of a old base.  Literally looks like you're walking into a true commissary at first - but the interior is very pretty and inviting.  The host/owner was very kind and seemed super accommodating when we told him that we were in a little bit of a rush, since we had to get back into the city at a certain time.  But the food didn't really seem to rush out - in fact we had to push back our arrival time in the city.

Overall, our experience was pleasant.  I really enjoyed the ambiance of the place - it would be perfect on a clear day for brunch.  I expect the view to be spectacular (unfortunately we were there for dinner on a fogy night).
author: Vicki C.

description: The menu changed recently. The rubbery meatballs are gone. Yay!  We had the short ribs, seafood "paella" and the whole bass. All were very good, albeit rather expensive. I think they raised their prices across the board. Cocktail list has changed too and were ok but not great. We sat at the chef's counter and watched them cook. Always enjoyable.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Parking in San Francisco!!!! Right out front or very close to a restaurant!!!!! A good restaurant!!!!

Now that's something to get excited about. Granted it was 6pm on a Monday, but still. 

We really enjoyed the salt cod fritters, although they could make the aioli a little easier to access. The roasted chicken was delicious, maybe the dates in the dish seem like an afterthought and weren't really integrated into anything else. 

Had a side of sauteed greens which was ok but nothing special. I brought most of them home and they were gritty on the reheating....don't know if they were dirty or??? We also had some corn which was dee-lish. Just a seasonal thing I think. 

The service was good, albeit the servers were stretched a little thin it seemed. But it's new and some kinks are getting worked out. What they say on the website about communal dining didn't seem to be the case when we were there - so I don't know if they found people weren't digging it. The good thing is that the tables are not jam packed in tight, so even tho the room got busy it didn't seem too noisy, and you felt like you had some privacy - the next table isn't all up in your bizness. 

The back room has tons of bar seating around the open kitchen, and we spotted Ms. Des Jardins herself back there, busy at work overseeing the action. It looked like a GREAT place to sit for lunch or maybe a few nibblies. 

Look forward to going back to try more things, like the octopus, etc...I'm not normally a huge fan of Spanish restaurants but The Commissary has just enough California in it to make it a happy marriage.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I went to The Commissary on a catch up date with someone I dated 4 years ago who I didn't like then and definitely like less now.  The food was amazing, my company was not.  I was annoyed up to the gills with this guy and slammed back two delicious tequila cocktails (SO PERFECT).  The chicken entree is their signature dish and it's so tender and tasty.  Small portions otherwise - prices are high but the restaurant is really cute with dark wood and the parking is SO easy in the Presidio.

A great spot for a date.... with someone you actually LIKE (or don't like). I am glad I went here and not somewhere else because I probably would've lost my temper had it not been for how nice the ambience was.
author: Sophia C.

description:
We were staying at the Inn, so this seemed a really good option. Oddly, they insisted the only table they had that would seat 3 was at 5:15. First night in San Francisco from NY, so not a problem... However, there were a good 10 to 15 tables that stayed empty around us for the 2 hours we were there...

The waitress was really sweet, but not great - they missed a couple of sides that we'd ordered (at least they didn't charge us). 

Food was good quality, if on the light side for portion size (unusually in the US) - especially with what should have been sharing plates.

All in all, good, but not great. The food isn't as high-end as they think, although the setting is lovely.
author: Mike R.

description:
It really should be a 2.5 stars but I wanted to be nice and rounded up.

A- : Environment - very interested location, they converted this living headquarter into a restaurant so it actually feels like you're walking into someone's home for dinner.  Small and intimate setting.  It was dimmed when we first arrived then the dimmed the lights even more as if it wasn't dark enough.

D : Lamb Shoulder - it was tough! That's a no no for me when it comes to lamb, I did not care for the way it was prepared in this sweet sauce.  The eggplant was ok

C: Chicken  - the fried chicken was again prepared in a sweet sauce,  I felt like every dish had sugar in it, usually I love sweets but it did not go well with any of the meat dishes.  The chicken liver pate on the bread was good, very smooth, a little more on the runny side than I would like

B+ : Grilled octopus - I enjoyed the charcoal taste and the chewy texture of the octopus was delightful

A++: Corn - very simple dish but my goodness, my favorite in taste and texture.  Every piece had a full on crunch to it, I would very much like the recipe and plan on duplicating this dish at home!

B: Cuttlefish - bland, it is what it is

B - : Ricotta Cheesecake -  I started loving ricotta cheesecake because of Colori Kitchen (it's absolutely amazing) but the way they make it here is very interesting.  It had more of a dry texture, not sweet at all, seems like the skimmed on the sugar when they shouldn't be 

C - : Churros- seriously, could have been satisfied with the vendors on the street of LA.  Yes, it was fresh and soft and warm but meh not worth $9

I'm glad I tried it because it was not your typical restaurant in a plaza or on main street but due to the flavoring I will not be returning.  However, my bf seem to enjoy the place and gives credit to their "innovative" menu so I guess I'd say try at your own risk.  Oh the service and uuuuuuberly sloooooww, grab something from taco bell before you come because the wait is long and the portions are tiiiiiny.
author: Lynda L.

description:
Part 2 of a successful but rather expensive dining out luncheon adventure with a friend.  After lunching somewhere else,  we decided to come here for dessert. 

A lucious 'taste' of chocolate custard with citrus slices, rice krispie-like crackles and chocolate wafer cookie crumbles.  A symphony of flavors.  A perfectly brewed cup of coffee to go with!   Ahhhhhh, so satisfying!

By the way, the main dining room was rustic sophistication.  So comforting on a windy and rainy day.

Service was welcoming and efficient.  

Portions are small, on the expensive side.  It was a very enjoyable experience, though.  Might have been the company I was with, too!
author: Debbie T.

description:
Get to The Commissary asap because this place is going to be popular! The space is inviting and the food is excellent.

TL:RL review

The food was excellent. We did not have a single dish we wouldn't order again. The octopus was cooked perfectly and was tender. The striped bass dish was a keeper even if it did have bacon in it that we were not told about (kind of a bad thing when the French Spouse is pescatarian). The kitchen was working smoothy and every dish was well thought out and delicious. Some could have used some salt but only minor tweaks are needed. The front of house not surprisingly for only 6 days open is still getting it's legs but the hostess and our server were both warm, attentive and helpful. Get here before it's hard to get into.

Long ass review:
We got there early for our reservation and were promptly seated. We sat at the large chef's counter where most of the 2 and 3 people groups were seated. The first dining room is mostly large tables for 5-15 people some of which were communal tables, the back dining room is basically the kitchen with a counter wrapped around it on three sides, two of which have a chef's counter. There are also two large high top tables. On two sides are walls of windows. Even with the kitchen the noise level was good. 

We ordered:
1. Salt cod fritters $9- 3 balls with lots of creamy fish, no fillers, perfectly deep fried served with dipping sauce. 

2.roasted artichoke salad $14 which was served with a perfectly poached eggs that made a creamy coating on the nicely charred artichoke. It hit all the right notes and would have been a great lunch item.

3.cured tuna, radish & fennel pollen $13 this was another salad and a tasty one but the portion of cured tuna was tiny and it was really just a radish salad which I make every week at home.

4.octopus, potatoes,olives and pimeton $14 this dish was the one that reminded me the most of the dishes I eat in Spain. There was generous portion of octopus heavily coated in pimeton. 

5.striped bass, clams,roasted almond-garlic picada $23, this was my favorite dish, it had the right balance of flavours and the broth was amazing. Bread is not listed on the menu and was not offered but we saw some brioche and got some to sop up the broth. The fish was cooked perfectly with crisp top and tender meat. There was also bacon that added even more flavour but sadly the pescatarian French Spouse wasn't aware was in there. But it was good enough that she kept eating it even when she knew.

We finished with two desserts even though we were full.

1.Churros and chocolate $9, tiny churros more doughy that I am used to but quite delicious

2. saffron-vanilla ice cream, pine nut turron, chocolate $9, this was a scoop of ice cream served with a piece of pine nut brittle, a few bits of a dehydrated nougat that tasted exactly like a Nestles Crunchie bar with sweet honey crunch and some chocolate sauce. I would have liked more nougat but it was delicious as it was.

We drank strawberry agua fresca, a latte and a flat priced unlimited sparkling water ($4). There are wines by the glass and by the bottle. Not a huge selection but diverse enough that most people will find something they like.

We spent about $50 a person. They don't add a tacky "health care" charge. I would plan on spending 30-60 per person.

Service-The menu is constantly changing and the front of house is still adjusting to the changes. Overall they were quite good and it's professional but friendly service. Traci Des Jardins was at the pass checking all the food. 

The space is understated but charming with solid wood tables and very comfy chairs including at the chef's counter. The lighting is good and besides the two dining rooms there is also a private dining room for 20.
The bathrooms are in a common area of the building and are unisex and wheelchair accessible although I didn't see a wheelchair ramp into the building. 

Parking is super easy at the moment and we parked right in front of the building.

They are currently no longer taking reservation either by seat-me or open table so get there while you can.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
The Commissary is Traci Des Jardins' take on the mini-trend of Spanish-influenced California cuisine.

Located in a nicely refurbished Presidio building, the lack of signage makes the new venue a little hard to find, but patrons that successfully complete the treasure hunt are rewarded with a simple, yet casually elegant, dining room. Be prepared to be friendly with your neighbors, however, since most seating is at communal tables with only a few two-tops and four-tops thrown in. The best seat in the house is at the chef's counter where diners can get up close and personal with the chefs as they rapidly sear and sauté their way through dishes.

Driven by sustainable ingredients mostly sourced from local providers, the menu changes regularly. On a recent visit, the blistered early season peppers ($9) were delicious and simply seasoned with sea salt. The dry-as-a-bone salt cod fritters ($9) were barely saved by a large application of lemon aioli. The grilled octopus ($14) served with, potatoes, olives, and pimeton was good, but the portion was ridiculously small. Ordered rare, the New York steak with mojo verde (a chimichurri-like sauce) and potato-idiazabal gratin was tender and juicy. 

With a melange of selections from Spain and California, the reasonably priced wine list features a variety of offerings well-suited to pair with des Jardins' dishes. On the other hand, cocktails are rather expensive and ultimately forgettable.

Slow and confused, service is lacking. Service staff seem young and inexperienced: water glasses go un-refilled, drinks arrive slowly, and follow-up was non-existent. Perhaps this will improve as des Jardins focuses on staff training, not just on getting the doors open.

While interesting, one expects more from award-winning Traci des Jardins. At least presently, Michael Chiarello and Coqueta need not worry about being dethroned as king of the Spanish-influenced trend in The City.
author: CJ G.

description:
Spending time on a military base growing up this name instantly caught my attention. For those of you who don't know, a commissary is the equivalent to a grocery store on a military base. So I already liked this place based on name alone!

Location: The restaurant is in a great location! We sat outside on the porch which overlooks a huge grassy lawn and the Bay. The Presidio (where this is located) is a great place to escape the craziness of the city. Also, parking is easy which is a huge plus is the city! 

Atmosphere: The restaurant layout is open and offers a variety of seating options including square tables (a personal favorite for groups) and counter seating around the entire kitchen in the back room. The whole place had a cool vibe about it and felt effortlessly trendy.

Food: We were there for lunch and I ordered the burger (tapenade on the side) and it was delicious. The meat was the high point and every bite was satisfyingly delightful. The fries were equally divine. Perfectly cooked on the outside creating the golden brown crisp equally over each fry and the inside was just the right softness. The harissa aioli that is served with the fries was not our favorite. We asked for ketchup instead since the seasoning in the aioli took away from the awesomeness of the well made fries. I would have much preferred a simple aioli or an exotic mustard. Perhaps worth revisiting the menu pairing on that one. 

Service: This is the area that needs the most improvement. The service was adequate, but definitely subpar. They were just kind of there, but didn't offer anything special or make you feel very welcomed. We tried to ask about the history of the restaurant for purposes of the blog, but this was met with shrugged shoulders and weak answers about when the restaurant opened. Every staff member should at least be able to answer that question.

Overall: I would go back for the burger and those fries (although I may bring my own aioli next time!). Love the atmosphere and think it would be a great spot with a big group or for a small office holiday party. Definitely room to improve on service, but overall I would give this a low 4. 

Extra Note: Given their name it would be a neat idea if they offered a special discount to military members like the real commissary. Just a thought!
author: 50 State By 30 T.

description:
I went here on Friday with my cousin and her husband. We had a reservation at 7, but arrived early and were seated promptly.

We ordered cocktails - which took a bit longer than expected... no big deal. For appetizers, we did the bacalao fritters and octopus. Both were delicious and finished right away. For entrée, I had the chicken. This was fantastic - cooked beautifully! The addition of medjool dates and liver mousse were superb.

It was my birthday in a few days, so the waiter surprised me with a cantaloupe melon sorbet. A tasty and refreshing palate cleanser to end the meal.

This is located in a beautiful area of the Presidio too. Walk towards the water and you'll see the Golden Gate up close!
author: Amy C.

description:
After 11 living in New York for 11 years, I'm constantly wanting a spot  with the New York energy, awesome food & cocktails, and a scene that energizes me.
