The Commissary,  a new Presidio restaurant by award-winning Chef Traci Des Jardins that features Spanish-influenced California cuisine is just that. Amazing food. Awesome scene. A fabulous team.  All in a charming Presidio location.   And, the Presidio is essentially in my back yard since I live in Pacific Heights.  What's more perfect than a fabulous restaurant close to home!!

The Commissary - After reading about the hype of The Commissary  I was ecstatic when it finally opened.  I was even more ecstatic to score a reservation for dinner with my Mom and my dear friend Katherine.  The Commissary seemed perfect for the occasion. I made a reservation "requesting" the Chef's counter (It's a request since they can't guarantee the Chef's Counter you can just request and hope). Upon arriving and checking in we were told there would be a bit of a wait. I had expected this since the Chef's Counter is always hard to score at restaurants . We all agreed it was worth the wait to be able to witness the creating firsthand.  Luckily, an old friend Malcolm (or a restaurant pal I should say) was taking fabulous care of us so when I realized the General Manager Malcolm was helping make the Chefs Counter happen I knew we were in good hands.  We were seated at the corner spot of the Chef's Counter (Spots #1, 2 & 3 which I later learned are the best seats because of the prime kitchen views and the privacy of the corner seats).   We had a view of the entire Kitchen and the two hot Chefs (as in the Chef's that prepare Hot Dishes); Chef Eric and Chef Preston.  After meeting Eric & Preston I soon realized not only was this going to be a fabulous tasting meal but also very engaging and fun. Both Eric & Preston were working extremely diligently, but also engaging us replying to questions and requests.  You have to give the Chefs props as on open Kitchen complicates their job tremendously. Not only are they expected to create fabulous food, they are also facing distractions from the Dining Room and Guests just a few inches away.

Overall, the food was amazing. Between the three of us we tried a ton. We started with a simple yet deliciously Fresh Green Salad, a Diced Beet Appetizer with Cheese, a Fried Pea & Cheese Ball (unexpectedly one of my favorites), White Beans with Diced Tomatoes, Cauliflower and two Entrees: The Steak & Chicken (loved them both equally and will definitely order again if they're still on the menu next time).  After consulting with the Pasty Chef we chose (or shall I saw the Birthday Girl) chose the Chocolate Fondant for dessert. Also amazing, no surprise....

I'm thrilled to report that what I thought would be a one time visit to a fabulous new hot spot close to home became me falling in love with a new neighborhood gem. A gem with fabulous food, an exciting lively scene, and an awesome team lead by a legendary chef. The only way to top this visit would be to meet Chef Traci on another visit! A girl can always dream... 101 Montgomery St, San Francisco, CA 94129. (415) 561-3600.

Thanks for checking out my post I hope you enjoy dining with The JetSetting Fashionista. Emily
author: JetSettingFashionista J.

description:
I was introuduced to this place by a friend who had read a review about this new restaurant called the The Commissary in the Presido. We have been eating lunch there for about 6 plus months.

I love this place it was once my second favorite restaurant to Bar Jules (being number 1) until they closed their doors. The ambience is great. I prefer the Chef's Counter because I have a chance to see the Chef's prepare the meals and I can ask a lot of questions and actually see the dish before ordering it.

I also like the counter because the Chef's are engaged with the people who are sitting there and talking to them eventhough at times it's extremeley busy. They never miss a beat! Always a smile on their faces.  My friend harrasses them all in fun and they are not phased, only join in on the fun.  With the exception of the dessert lady, I have never seen her smile but her desserts she prepare are delicious! Therefore she must be a happy employee :)

Yes, it's a little pricey but the ingrediants they use are local, in season and fresh. I'm sure that plays a part in the menu price. Everything we have ordered (we share dishes) have been tasteful no complaints.

It's a place to try when your in the area
author: Lois C.

description:
The atmosphere is great for dining.  A big open area and the tables are spaced apart. They have a private room with this great barn door but since we were sitting close to this room, I wish they'd close the door fully so we didn't have to listen to the loud noises from the large group.  It sounded like they were either watching a sports game or playing a video game.  
Our waiter was efficient. Our appetizers and entrees in a timely manner but the dessert took a really long time such that even Jr. Yelper was complaining about the wait.  This happened when the restaurant started to fill up (after 7PM) with customers.
Our choices:
The cod fritters were OK, $12.  It was slightly salty but when you bit into these balls of flaky fish, you could tell it was fishy tasting.  I wouldn't order again.
The fairly large size of empanada, $7, was pretty good.  Hubby said there were raisins in it, I could not tell from the bite I had.  
Entrees:
1. Trout - I loved this dish.  2 fillets of tender, orange fish with a nice crunch to the pan-seared skin.  Didn't like the vegts. served with it. A bit too tart. $32.
2. There were 2 orders of the roasted chicken - pieces of tender, moist chicken.  I only had one bite but it was delicious.  Jr. Yelper said portions were too small.$27 each.
3. New York steak, $35.  2 chunks of med rare steaks which looked a bit more rear than med rare.  The meat was also tender.
Hubby and I had sangrias. Red for him, White for me. I really liked the White Sangria, but would've liked a bit more fruity flavor to it, $8 each.

Dessert :  We were all full but decided to share an order of lemon ricotta.
The lemon ricottas, 4 small donut holes coated with sugar. I couldn't taste the lemon flavor but the dessert was good. And they gave you 4 tiny pieces of jelly pieces. 
What I like about this restaurant is the atmosphere, ability to find parking and the quietness of being in a federal park. It's a gem in the middle of urban chaos.
author: Ry T.

description:
Good not great.

Walked in at 6pm with no reservation on Saturday night and they had no availability but offered up the table in the waiting area which was worth a star right there.

We wanted to keep room for the churros at the end so we went for small plates.

Blistered peppers - not bad, not super tasty.  Some were spicy some not.

Salt cod fritters - pretty good, fishy but yummy

Crispy new potatoes - tasty but not overly so.  Also not so crispy

Sweet pea and ham croquetas - second thing to come out and one of the best things delivered to the table.  Lightly breaded but lots of great flavor

Octopus and potatoes - we renamed it 'papas y pulpo'.  Definitely the best thing to make its way from the kitchen into my mouth.  Octopus was very tender and who cared about anything else in the dish because yum.

Churros with chocolate and rum milk jam - it's churros.  It'd be nice if the chocolate were Mexican style hot chocolate with a little kick.  Next time I don't need the chocolate but the other goo was tasty 

Arroz con leche - sweet but not overly so.  Cookies in the bottom were a nice treat in an otherwise ok dessert.
author: steve a.

description:
Expensive. Which is ok if the food was on par. 
But it's not.
Octopus overcooked. Chewy. But good flavor. But the octopus was cheweier than the potatoes! By like a factor of 10!
The pork ribs...ew ew. Boiled, grilled and smothered. The meat was bland, chewy and watery. For the love of god please don't boil ribs. Wtf. I am shocked that a chef today would put this dish out. Pay the plane tickets go to the south eat ribs. Avoid this disaster!
The chickpeas. Ok. 
Blistered peppers. Cooking school 101. Make sure everything is the same size so it all cooks even. So no the case.

Not going to be returning.
author: Aruna P.

description:
Briefly put, The Commissary has unschooled service and quite good food.

On entering I was led to the Chef's Counter in the back room.    It was empty save one group of ladies and the host seated me immediately next to this group.  Uncomfortable.  And the server assumed I was part of that group for some considerable time.  After a bit I asked if I might move a seat over; after considerable consultation that was permitted.  But the next group in was seated immediately next to me.  Again, uncomfortable.  There is a certain mindlessness going on here.  But the food can compensate, at least in part.  

A salad of little gems came with some cherry tomatoes and fried bread.  Very fresh, very good, but it left me wishing that there was a bit more on the plate for the price.  

A main of alaskan halibut was nicely seared yet remained moist.  Two large shrimp were also swimming in the the complexly seasoned broth and these likewise were moist and tasty.  

A side of roasted corn was coated in corn nuts and was prepared with some cheese or other that separated from the corn.  Not to mind, the cheese was nice anyway.  Likewise the corn.  

All in all, good food that deserves better service.
author: David D.

description:
Had dinner here with my fiancée on the Monday immediately after Father's day. Figured that the restaurant would be relatively empty considering most people went out to dinner the previous day. Nope, all dining rooms tables were full, a testament to the quality of this restaurant. 

First off, the prices are surprisingly reasonable for this caliber of restaurant. We ordered four small plates and two desserts to get a thorough taste of the menu. Everything was excellent, fresh and local and the first two words that come to mind. We had the salt cod fritters, albondigas with spiced yogurt, brentwood corn w/ espelette, mahon , corn nuts and the smoked pt.reyes salmon. 

The best treat was the opportunity to sit at the chef's counter. You get an up close and personal window into the culinary art of this restaurant. The chef's even took the time to talk to us to ensure everything was up to par.
author: Eric C.

description: Loved everything about this place. Sat at the open kitchen counter and enjoyed watching and chatting with the chefs. Food and service were excellent. The Bombas were the bomb!
author: Chris S.

description:
Two stars for service and overall experience, 3 stars for food.
Came here last night to celebrate my birthday with my husband. Restaurant was not very busy when we were first seated. Apparently for birthdays they print your name on your menu. They forgot my special menu at first but brought it to me after we already ordered.
Speaking of menu, study up your French, kids, because it's only half in English. Had to use google translate to know what I was ordering. I guess that's not that big of a deal but our waiter never offered to explain it until he saw us using our phones.
We got the deep fried cheeseballs and they were amazeballs, and the lamb meatballs, which were tasty but a bit cold.
Then we waited and waited and waited for our mains. Definitely over 30 minutes. We understand kitchens get backed up but our waiter never bothered to check in with us. He breezed by at one point to say "2 more minutes" but that turned into about 15.
My husband got the steak which was delicious. I got a bland very overcooked piece of bass. I asked my waiter for salt. He never brought it. Had to ask another waitress, who brought it 5 minutes later. I basically had to wait 10 more minutes to get my salt to eat my entre.
They brought me a little strawberry sorbet with a candle which was lovely. And we got the chocolate cookie sandwich with olive oil ice cream. Also very lovely.
To sum up, could have been a much better experience if our waiter was friendlier and more attentive and food was consistently good. Your experience might be better if the kitchen has their shit together and service steps their game up, but we will not be back.
author: Alisa L.

description:
I have been looking forward to trying the Commissary for awhile now. All the tables were held for reservations at lunch so we sat in the back at the counter where we could watch the cooks make the food. This was awesome. I love watching chefs work and the cooking area was big, clean, and the counter was as big as the size of the table anyway. 
We had the green bean salad, which was lovely. There was fresh green beans and snap peas along with capers and a perfect light dressing. Then we got the onion soup that was good but the green compote on it was delicious! Then the fries (which were cooked to perfection) and the mushroom toasts. The toasts were a little heavy and greasy, but a filling vegetarian dish which can be hard to get. Overall, a great location, great staff and a fun experience with good food.
author: Marisa L.

description:
If I could give 2.5 stars I would. The food was solidly good, but not outstanding - definitely at least 3 stars but the service was incredibly inattentive and our overall experience wasn't a positive one.

I was happy that we were seated a private table for 2 as I was really surprised to see on here that even if you have a reservation you are sometimes seated at the communal table (wtf???). It took our server a really long time to come over and get our drink order and then another long stretch to actually get our drinks. When she finally brought the drinks, she didn't ask if we were ready to order or if we had any questions about the menu - she was about to leave again and I had to basically stop her from walking away so we could get our order in. I'm glad I did because our food also took forever to come.

Long story short, she totally forgot our bread order (we had to ask for it halfway through the dinner) and the food came out very very slooowly. She also never once asked if we wanted more drinks (we had both finished ours before the meal was over) and even the dessert which was not something that had to be cooked took forever to come out of the kitchen.

The food itself was good, but not great. For a Traci des Jardins restaurant I expected more in terms of service, quality of what you get for your money, etc. It's worth mentioning that the weekend evening that we went the crowd was skewed heavily toward the older side (50s-60s and up). There were several tables taking very bright flash photography repeatedly (it looked like it was someone's birthday) as well as a table of older folks who were using super bright flashlights to see the menu and kept accidentally shining them in our faces (it wasn't that dark in the restaurant). For being a tapas restaurant I also expected it to be romantic, candlelit and cozy or fun (upbeat music, etc) and it was very quiet.

It was not the fine dining experience I had in mind. If you go, you'll likely enjoy the food although perhaps not the service or the overall ambiance.
author: Britt M.

description: Just really bad. 3 out of 7 dishes were tasty. Service was beyond slow. Took 20 minutes to get our drinks and 40 minutes to get our food. There are so many more restaurant options out there - don't waste your time here. I will bet that they'll be out of business within a year. Hopefully a restaurant that cares about timing, flavor and clientele will take the space over.
author: Adam J.

description:
Nice atmosphere, and very nice hosts who were able to get us a table with no reservation. We waited at the bar and enjoyed a nice glass of Rioja. 
We were seated a a large communal table which was nice. 
Unfortunately  the tapas were mediocre.  Definitely not the great stuff you can get in any dive in Spain.   
The fennel salad was the best, the empanadas had too much pastry and not enough filling.  They used the same aioli sauce for the bacalau croquettas which is a shame because a nicer sauce could have been used.   The bacalau croquettes were very good.   The octopus was too "blackened" for my taste, and too spicy for my wife. 
Overall a nice atmosphere is very nice, nice minimalist design, nice servers, but the food is overpriced.  160USD for 1 beer, 3 Riojas and 4 tapas is over the top.
author: JJ B.

description:
This place is amaze-balls! Excuse my language....but, I can't be helped. 

Great location-right next to the Walt Disney Museum. I just love this area because of the historic buildings. It's a little tucked away area in San Francisco that is fun to walk through. On Thursday nights there are also food trucks and wine outside the restaurant on the large lawn. Great for pre-drink before your amazing meal.

For drinks we had the white sangria which was perfectly refreshing. 

For appetizers we had the papas bravas and salt cod fritters. Both were delicious, and I'd go back again just for appetizers and drinks if i was in the area. 

For dinner I had the roast chicken and it was so good that I tried to replicate it at home with zero success. The secret I'm told is the Sherry vinegar, and....that's about all I know about that. God damn that chicken was good, I'm salivating just writing about it. 

Dessert was OK. Not my favorite given how delicious everything else was, but I was also stuffed. The portions are also very generous, so make sure you come hungry and don't eat the bread they give you if you want any chance at finishing your meal. 

Our servers were great and super friendly, you can tell that they actually care about your experience (which is something that most restaurants lack nowadays), so the servers are a precious commodity. 

We were seated in the back where we could walk the kitchen staff cook the meals and see the chef yell at the line cooks. Pretty awesome if you're a food nut. It gives a real peek into how seriously these people take their food and their dedication to standards and a perfect experience. 

Go there now. It's an SF chronicle 100 top restaurant in SF, so I highly recommend you give it a taste.
author: Heather T.

description: I've been here twice, two years apart. Most of the food has been excellent, but the ridiculous glasses used for wine-by-the-glass and the equally ridiculous small pours (for $15 and up glasses of wine) really put me off this place. This time I had the paella with scallops, mussels, clams, and chorizo. It was really good EXCEPT that the few mussels were quite small and the clams were so tiny they might as well not have been there. Come on, for $35?
author: Malcolm R.

description:
As I read some of the reviews below, it's so hard for me to imagine some of the poor experiences people have had at this place.  I have been here several times and I always come out of The Commissary thinking it is one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  The service is always amazing, and the food is so carefully crafted and prepared, not to mention the taste! I think this is the first place I have had octopus cooked correctly - nothing tough about it and the flavors exceptional. Also, I'm not one to order bread at a restaurant unless it is free, but the Sourdough and dipping sauce that is currently on the menu is so so good. 

If you make a reservation you must must MUST sit at the kitchen bar.  It's a treat to see the cooks, the pastry chef and the manager working and checking on the food being prepared. You really begin to appreciate the work and effort that is put into its preparation.  

I always look forward to dinner at The Commissary.  I can't wait to go tonight!!
author: Alicia L.

description: The experience is incredible, particularly at the chef's counter. The ingredients couldn't be fresher. And Daz is an incredible waiter.
author: Paul G.

description:
Bad experience. We went on a Friday and got seated promptly. Our waitress suggested we order quickly because a party of 14 was incoming and she thought the kitchen might get slow. We ordered our tapas and mains. The queso bombas were delicious, the other tapas were so-so (potatoes and a bread dish). Then our mains came. The chicken was okay, the salad was fine and the trout was good. Then we waited, and waited, and waited... We could not get anyone's attention to clear our table. We just sat there. I finally had to stand up to find our waitress to get her to come over. It still took awhile, and when someone finally came we just wanted our check. They nonetheless set our table for dessert, which we were not going to have. They brought us complimentary sorbet, but never brought my chicken that I had asked to take home. By then I was too annoyed to fuss about that. 

Service can make or wreck a meal. On this nite it was the latter. Disappointing.
author: Julie K.

description: What a fantastic dinner! We enjoyed the food and a show as we were seated at the periphery of their open kitchen area. The bombas could almost be a dessert. Warm fried cheese with honey glaze. The bread was the perfect balance of crisp and soft nestled on a bed of goat cheese. The stone fruit salad was a perfect reflection of the seasonal fruits on a bed of lettuce  and nuts. The chicken was to die for. Must have been brined. Very moist and perfectly cooked with crispy skin, not too greasy. Smothered with a caramelized Onion sauce and topped with a liver spread toast. The desserts were beautifully dressed with flower pedals and sauces. Everything was visually pleasing. Service was on point. I was thoroughly impressed! I'm bringing friends back here!
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Last week my wife and I had a disappointing dining experience at the Commisary in the presidio. The owner also owns Jardiniere in Hayes valley, one of our favorite spots, so we were surprised.

* The Salt Cod Fritters and Croquettas came out first. The two dishes looked so similar that we had to ask the server if they were two different items. One came with an orange aioli and the other a lemon aioli, again so similar that we were confused. We sent both items back.

* For mains we got the chicken and the trout. Both were under-seasoned, uninspired and bland.

We let the server know we weren't happy with the meal, and I also tweeted about it as we finished.

As we left, someone (the chef?) came up behind us and attacked me for tweeting about the meal. He was pissed. He said I was "hiding behind a tweet". Sorry dude, but I wasn't hiding. The tweet has my name and face on it. 

I would have been happy to talk to him about why we didn't enjoy the meal and give him feedback, but he had no interest in that. He just wanted me to delete my tweet. 

It was one of the most bizarre dining experiences of my life.
author: Sachin A.

description:
It was opening day. So, there are a few kinks in the service but our time at the bar was rewarded with tasty cocktails and appetizers. Dinner looks good, but that's for another night.

The location is beautiful and the space inviting but, I predict, subject to change. In particular, the bar footprint is rather small.
author: David D.

description:
Ate lunch here a couple of weeks ago with my husband for my birthday and we were both totally disappointed.  

We walked in to an almost empty restaurant  which is fine by me.  I don't judge a place by how full or empty it is but guess where we were seated? In a corner table that was so close to the next table of 2 that I could barely fit my butt between them.  Oh!  That table was occupied by other folks who were talking so loud and there was another couple also bedside them.  Man! Couldn't they have spread us out a little?  I mean, the whole place was empty but they crammed all of us in the tightest spot!

As for the food, tasted like overpriced, under -seasoned cafeteria food. We had their pate which had the texture and taste of rubber, mushroom soup that didn't taste like anything at all, kale salad that was also quite disappointing and a mediocre burger (I prefer In and Out's for a fraction of the price).  The fries were good but for $8, they better be!  I ate the hell out of those suckers and basically had a birthday frie fest as my birthday lunch.  Thanks for the carb load, Commissary.
author: Maite O.

description:
The food is 4 star, but the service was maddening non-existent. We went there as a big group for a birthday dinner, with a big cake. The dining room is beautifully done, busy yet still elegant.

First we asked for wine recommendations, our waitress admitted that she's no expert but she'll send the sommelier over, which is a totally fine thing to do and say. We ordered a bunch of starters, appetizers, and entrees. The sommelier wasn't there yet when our entrees came, so boyfriend asked another server for the sommelier again since our waitress was no where to be found. The sommelier first recommended a $300 bottle wine (??), huh??, we were obviously planning to order more than 1 bottle, but that put off our desire to order more. We landed on a great wine at around $100, which is a good price but we did not order any more wines.

After the dinner is served, we were waiting for our cake to arrive for a long long time, our waitress was drifting around as if we are none of her business at all. We were enjoying each others' company so it was OK. The cake came, we sang, they took it back to slice them. The cake was amazing but super rich, some of us wanted water, some wanted coffee or tea, yet the waitress was still no where to be found. This whole time, nothing was offered, no water, no coffee or tea. The waitress was still wandering around "avoiding" any eye contacts. The conversation at the table started to circle around the lack of service. 

Finally, boyfriend got up to talk to the chef, simply said the food was excellent, but the service was the worst we've ever had anywhere. The waitress came to apologize with her eyes red, nothing could really help her at this point. The check came, it was only $195 with all the drinks we had (pitcher of sangria, cocktails, and a bottle of wine), and pretty much everything on the menu, some double orders. Either they took off a lot of the items on the check, or it was not our check at all.

Ugh, such a frustrating experience. If it weren't for my wonderful friends, that would've been a birthday dinner ruined badly.
author: Yuchi C.

description: Had a stellar dinner here last Saturday night. We loved every dish and the service was attentive (although we did come before the rush). The house-cured roe and cod fritters were perfection. We also got the crispy potatoes, della fattoria bread, which comes with olive oil and sea salt, and the asparagus side, beautifully grilled. For the main course, we split the trixat, which was a crispy potato rectangle served with a cheese sauce, trumpet mushroom, and sauteed leeks, garnished with miner's lettuce. It was an elegant and satisfying vegetarian dish. For dessert, we had the burnt honey custard with chocolate jam. My mouth is watering just thinking about our meal! I highly recommend the Commissary!
author: Julia M.

description:
Had a delightful luncheon salad, and my dining companion ordered it 'vegan' with chicken and cheese removed.  She was charged the regular price..with no offer to provide more kale or other ingredients.  Is that the norm?

Also we attempted to get our server's attention after paying the bill to order some coffee and tea...and when we asked her, she asked us to 'wait a minute' and rushed off...never to return until we finally got up to leave.  She then raced over to apologize. Too late!
author: Jeannie B.

description:
Totally love the new Commissary

Beautiful space in one of the most gorgeous neighborhood 

Food in my opinion is more norther African influence than Spain but loved the spices. Octopus squid with chorizo is a must. And then there is the wine programme - great great great Spanish finds. Malcolm has crafted a great list.

One of my top 5 SF fun dining
author: Bernard D.

description:
Awesome spot

Check out these dishes:

Patatas bravas
Bombas de queso
Chicken
Steak
Chick pea
author: Alec H.

description:
The venue itself is beautiful.  Service was good, but not all that engaging.  We had the burgers (ordered medium).  The patty resembled a frozen patty (incredibly thin) and was essentially well done (not sure how you could cook such a small paty anything other than well done).  

I'd recommend this spot for a drink.  Dine elsewhere for the money.
author: Henry B.

description:
I work down the street from the restaurant, so a friend and I decided to try lunch here. The result was a very plain, overpriced, disappointing bland hamburger accompanied by an unimaginative pile of arugula. $14 later (not counting tax and tip) I was craving McDonalds. 

Needless to say, I'd never go back for lunch. I probably wouldn't risk dinner based on this experience as well as my previous, even more unsatisfying, adventure at "Jardiniere". 

My advice, don't waste your time or money here.
author: Tino N.

description: Last night I went to The Commissary in the Presidio and had an exceptional experience on all levels from service, to the cocktails, from the so cool experience of watching the chef do his magic in the open kitchen, to the ambiance, to being able to actually hold a conversation to the FOOD!  This is my current favorite restaurant.  It is convenient for both city dwellers and Marinites.  Special call outs to our bartender Chris F, chef Rogelio, GM Tessa and our server Roxanne.  Flawless, thank you.
author: R. S.

description: We ate here for the first time Saturday night and the food was delicious though the service left a lot to be desired.  Our dinner waiter greeted us with an unusual comment about us waiting to judge the service till the end of the meal.  He actually seemed to be drunk.  He was sloppy when he poured the wine, our entry was on the cool side when it came.  Perhaps that was because after the appetizer course he presented us with the dessert menu!  We mentioned that we hadn't even gotten our main course yet.  There was another course that he never delivered.  I can't remember his name but he is from Venezuela and I am sure that is not how they do things there.  Would return for the food but not for this waiter!
author: Polly H.

description: I never knew this place even existed in the presidio.  Very undercover, but a pretty fantastic find.  I started off with a glass of bubbly and tombo tuna app.  It was so delicious I could've eaten 2 of them.  For an entree I had the fresh halibut and clams which was also delicious.  I'm excited to come back and try some of the other things on their menu.
author: Rachael S.

description: Great food, great service, beautiful and pleasant atmosphere. Spanish cuisine, colonial yet modern decor. We arrived with no reservations but the hostess was more than happy to set us up in community seating or the fabulous bar. I will definitely be taking my mother back to this place when she visits.
author: Winter G.

description:
Sooooooo disappointing. Love the setting but the food and service are very bad. And - WOW - the prices are the highest I have seen in SF.
We left hungry and not happy.
author: Anna C.

description:
Super overpriced drinks that vary greatly in size and value. The woman bartender was NOT friendly and somewhat incompetent. She tasted every single drink she made. The drink menu was not well detailed and each item required explanation. Although the place is stated as spanish and all drinks have sherry in them. Weird! We did not tip!
The menu was not appealing.
author: Carol m.

description: What a fun find in the Presidio! Headed here for dinner after date night at House of Air (don't ask). We sat at the kitchen bar and enjoyed a few cocktails . . . and ordered the bomba queso, patatas bravas, steak and chicken entrees, fried eggplant, and brussel sprouts. The food was well timed, and it was really fun to watch it all being prepared and plated. We were to stuffed to the brim to check out dessert, but it's on the list for next time.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Great venue in a historical building with beautiful surroundings. Lunch was very enjoyable....good service paired with delicious food and wine.

The only slight disappointment was the small amount of wine when purchased by-the-glass.  Other than that, excellent meal.
author: Daniel W.

description:
5 star food, 1 star service.  

Food:  The food was nothing short of amazing.  I had the bacon wrapped trout with the octopus to start.  Both were fantastic.  Everything my guest had was great as well.  The portions were ample and i felt a good value. 

Ambiance:  Very nice design.  Pretty loud if you are sitting in the front, I could barely hear my friend. I would suggest sitting at the bar in the back room. 

Service:  Hands down the worst service I have had in memory.  
At least 20 mins before we spoke to a waiter and could order a drink
Ordering for dinner was rushed.  They never cleared our first course plates before serving the main course.  ** There wasn't enough room on the small table for everything.  After dropping off the main course we didn't have silverware.  I literally tried waving someone down with my arm but didn't have any luck.  
Ordering a second drink was a hassle as well.  

I really want to go back, as the food was delicious  but I don't think i can brave the service experience again.

Proceed with caution.
author: Karen C.

description: This was truly a wonderful dining experience! My sister and I made a 6 pm reservation for a Friday night. We were seated in the back by the chef's station so we could see the food being prepared and had the chance to interact with the chefs a bit. It was a one of kind experience. All of the food and cocktails were delicious from starters to dessert. The wait staff were friendly and attentive. Overall, the meal had a high end feel while remaining accessible. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a memorable, authentic, personalized and quality dining experience in SF! Thank you, Commissary!
author: Gabriella D.

description: This was my first time to eat at the Commissary. I went to dinner with my co workers and had a delicious dinner. Our server was nice and Sid, he entertained us and very generous and welcoming.  Look forward to another caus it again soon. Thank you!
author: Hula G.

description:
I work above the Commissary, which means I've had the opportunity to check it out pretty often.  I've been there both for sit down meals, and for grab n go lunches.

Sit down Meal - had the chicken - it was good, and tasty, but not as good as my mother's chicken, and for that price, I want it to be.  

Grab N Go.  I've gone here more than I'd like to admit when I just need to quickly grab something to eat and can't risk going half a block away.  But it is NOT my first choice.

Sandwiches here used to be expensive, then they lowered the price and they got really good, and now they've increased the price a bit again, but have by far decreased the amount of whatever is inside.  It's like a bread sandwich.  Plus their Serrano ham, which should be delicious, last time came full of gristle and way way way too much fat (I know that some comes with it, but no need to put a whole slab), and they put pickles in there... it made me actually gag into a trash can.  Not cute.
 
Little Gem Salad - area you freaking kidding me?! This is an extortion!  I feel like i have been hustled.  $14.50 for a salad that has $2 worth of ingredients - an egg, some cheese, fried bread and run of the mill lettuce.  This is exorbitant, and it's not even that good!  Next time I will skip lunch if I can't make it to the Disney cafe half a block away, which has salads chock full of way more ingredients and healthier options, to the tune of $8.50.

In short, over the past few months I feel like Commissary's quality has been steadily declining while their prices increase.
author: Jessica H.

description: Fantastic place! We had great fun, gorgeous food and lovely drinks. Perfect staff and since we sat at the kitchen bar we saw the chefs at work. Every item was freshly prepared. Deserts to die for!!
author: Javon F.

description:
If you have a dainty appetite and a big wallet, then The Commissary is probably for you. Dined here at lunch and our bill was about $91 not including tip for 4 ppl. What did we feast on, you might be wondering? Our "feast" consisted of 1 soup, 1 salad, 1 side of fries, 2 burgers, 1 chicken "basquaise," and 2 beers (bottled Anchor and Trumer). 

The burgers and soup were relatively substantial portion-wise but the chicken was more like an appetizer despite being priced at the high end of the lunch menu ($14). The dish came with two measly lightly fried drumsticks sitting in a thin layer of tomato-y liquid. The drumsticks must have been taken from a chicken on a diet and tasted just okay. The accompanying potatoes were both soggy and hard at the same time....an accomplishment I wish I never had to come across. I was hoping for a hearty stew, but this dish would not have filled up a small child....who had just eaten.

The squash was just a single layer of squash rounds covered in greens on a salad plate. The fries were oversalted. Didn't try the burger....it comes medium rare unless otherwise instructed.

The service was excellent and the space is gorgeous. Pretty full for a Tuesday lunch.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
Great lunch there today after a walk to the Golden Gate Bridge. Delicious salad and a bean/sausage/clam stew.  Sat at the kitchen bar and had a nice conversation with one of the cooks. 

Can't wait to return for dinner.
author: Dean B.

description:
Had dinner here with friends last night, Friday at 6pm.  We had tried to get in before without reservations, but made them this time a few days before and were seated promptly.  

The menu entres are rather limited, but we liked what we had.  The food in general is interesting and well made.  Some interesting combinations like pork and clams that worked well.  

Some of the portions are rather small, however, like the cheese plate which consisted of 5 small bits of cheese and 5 small bits of bread.  Not much to share. 

Cost was about $90 each including a glass of wine and tip.  Not cheap, but within reason.

Service was a bit slow, but not too bad.  We clocked in at 2 hours for dinner before the rush at 8pm.  

The wine pour was the stingiest I have ever seen, maybe 4 ounces for $14.  Not a great value.  

The place got noisy as the night went on and when full, it is hard to converse.  Maybe the back room with the seats around the kitchen is different.  That looks like a fun place.  We sat in the main room as one of our party "didn't care to see how they made the food".

Parking is ample and free.  Woohoo!
author: Alan B.

description:
Food was good. The location and decor were very cool. #1 issue that they can resolve quickly - wine pours were tiny 4 oz. cups for $14! First we had $4 dollar toast in SF (which I am actually quite fond of despite the pricing), now it's $14 for a 4 oz. pour.

2 options here Traci, cut the prices in half or at least increase the pours to SF city standards.

Thank you,

Pete
author: Peter T.

description:
I wish I tried the Commissary on a day that was not Valentine's day.  I wish that when I made a reservation for a big family dinner, they sent me a warning that it only had a prix fixe menu for the special occasion.  

Instead,  I was stuck with a crazy bill of $70 per person, with a kid who had nothing to order (wasn't going to pay $70 for him to eat 30% of his food.)  

The food was fine, but I don't know how anyone could possibly ever have a splendid experience when your meal options were basically like meat? fish? or veggie?  I was looking forward to sharing small plates (isn't that the essence of Spanish cuisine?) with such a large group of people.  But instead we were looking at each other, like "how is your salad?"  "It's fine; it's the same as yours."

And I won't go on about the steep price, because I guess it's like an accepted thing  that if you want to eat out on Feb. 14, you need to pay a surcharge (because you are depriving a table from a nice, freshly in love couple who are now starvign because of you??)

Anyway, I don't get it.  It could have been better. But it just wasn't.
author: Candice B.

description:
Guys-you open almost 30 mins later than advertised. On a weekend. And on Memorial Day no less. You obviously have a captive audience based on your location and the limited to zero options for daytime food, except for maybe the bowling alley. At the prices you're charging I had hoped and expceted quality cuisine. You did not deliver. And I've had faster service at the DMV.

I was better off trying my luck at the bowling alley.
author: Tripp S.

description:
I'm really disappointed in The Commissary. I went in today for lunch shortly after they opened at 11:30 and while the location and service are great, the food is really lackluster.

PROS: Great location in the Presidio, gorgeous interior decor, lots of alcoves and bar space to have an intimate meal or meeting in a big space.  Great service from the staff, very welcoming and informed about the menu. 

CONS: The food. Almost everything was mediocre to bad tasting, but came out looking very nice.
 - Burger: was okay but overpriced considering it doesn't come with anything alongside it but a handful of arugula. The bun on the burger was the best part, but the patty itself was pretty thin.
 - Fries: not outstanding, really expensive ($8) for a dish of plain fries with some seasoned mayo; frozen or prepared fries, not made in-house. 
 - Trinxat: was from-the-fridge cold inside, and just two scoops of mashed potatoes with cabbage, scallion, and salt, also served with a handful of arugula. These are clearly scooped up from a prepared batch and seared as patties before serving, and they lacked any flavor and the sear was more just color than a crisp sear. I've had this dish other places and it typically has ham or bacon in it, with a crusty top or bottom to create texture and depth of flavor -- The Commissary did none of that. 

TL;DR -- dinner is probably their stronger suit here; the menu is much larger and hopefully better prepared. Lunch was overpriced for mediocre quality food. Service and location are great, but in a city with GREAT food everywhere (especially in The Marina/Pacific Heights) this place isn't gonna make it if they don't put out better food. I'd also say they should consider offering some olives or spanish almonds, etc on the table to much on before your food arrives.
author: Laura J.

description:
Much, much potential...but it's gonna take some steps to get there.

The dishes sound delicious and almost meet expectations. The underlying flavors are there, and they are right - yet, there is a seasoning miss across the board. The steak was nicely spiced, yet also bland. The nectarine salad was refreshing, yet unlavored. 

A far greater miss than the food was the service. Had our waitress been engaged and excited and anything less than tragically bored and detached, I might have overlooked the average culinary experience, especially in light of the newness of the place. 

All of that said, the space is cool - it's exciting to see what's happening in the Presidio. And again, there is a lot upside there - keep working at it!
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Just OK, nothing fancy. The food is just average (at best).

Presentation is not good.  Stay away from the steak, it's chewy with very little flavor. 

The service is fine and our waitress was very nice. 

For the price,  there are much better restaurants in San Francisco to choose from. Go somewhere else.
author: Scott O.

description: great food.  good service (not great) would give them another star if the wine pours weren't so stingy!  I don't think I have ever seen such a small pour!
author: Hank B.

description:
Came here for dinner and was delighted with the entire experience.  I was concerned because other reviews gave the service low marks but my evening was superb.  Our waitress was extremely attentive to all our needs.  I really appreciated how she walked us through the menu explaining what dishes where what and overall made us feel really welcome.

Here's what we had:
- Salt cod fritters: delicious and good portion (there were 4 of them, good for 2 people)
- Brussel sprouts: yummy side dish, loved the chorizo and sauce on them
- Bread: I was a little skeptical that bread costs $5 but it's worth it.  You get a good 10 to 12 slices with olive oil and salt. It felt like a small tapas dish.  It was well worth it in my mind. 
- Jamon wrapped trout: Delicious!!  The sauce was out of this world, fish was so tender ad perfect combination of salty and savory. 
- Lemon ricotta fritters with espresso cream - AMAZING way to end the meal!  They tasted like a sweet donut meets lemon pound cake. Wow. 

My party and I sat at the bar in the back that overlooked the kitchen.  It was a unique view into the happenings of the kitchen an a cool experience to see up close all the meals being prepared.  We chatted with the chefs and they were all very friendly and eager to provide incite into what they were preparing.  When I come back, this is where I will request to sit.
author: Jessie W.

description: Warm eloquent server was very attentive. Got right in with our reservations. Timing was excellent from appetizers to deserts. We ordered 3 appetizers which were all lovely. The ny steak, chicken dinner, & roasted corn were excellent. Although the true challenge was picking dessert. The options had me feeling like a greedy little girl with a whole chocolate cake. We ended up getting the corn flan, chocolate cookie ice cream sandwich and the berries and ice cream. While there were just the two of us to share it. We enjoyed every bite. I will be back soon and suggest you give it a try.
author: Jamie S.

description: Great new restaurant in the Presidio. Comfy casual design, amazing Spanish tapas, get the sangria or a fancy cocktail and the homemade bread, olives and cheese balls, ohh the cheese balls. Entrees solid too, especially the roasted chicken and sides. And don't miss the homemade cookie ice cream sandwiches. Wonderful!
author: Peter H.

description: Well, unlike quite a few people I really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere.  My complaint was with the service.  We had a charming waitress but after handing us the menus she asked if she could explain the menu to us and proceeded to go through the entire menu line by line.  Now, first, she should know that most diners in San Francisco have read their fair share of menus and actually we are pretty good at figuring them out.  Also, if I don't understand some ingredient, I will ask ask.  This was a date but I felt like there was third wheel with us and as nicely as I attempted to cut her off, she never quite got the point. So, service needs work. Otherwise, very good.  So, if you want to save yourself some time - tell her you've been there before.  Problem solved.
author: Virginia T.

description: My wife and I had a absolutely wonderful dinner at The Commissary.  Both entrees - Crispy Lamb Shank and the Ranch Trout - were to die for!  The dessert Double Chocolate (ice cream sandwich) was another masterpiece and perfect cap to our meal.
author: Dennis H.

description: Great food and great service!! I never write a review but I called ahead to say it was my mom and grandmother's birthday and they printed menus with their names on it and the manager popped champagne for us. And then they put a candle in our dessert. It was so generous and such nice touches to make the evening so specia.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Food was very enjoyable. Service was (let me put it bluntly) terrible. We ordered a decent selection including: gem
Salad, pork albondigas, crispy potatoes, seasonal peppers, roast pork shoulder, bass, and steak. All the food was delicious. But (the server was very courteous), the service just plain sucked. We had to wait a very long time for everything. I can elaborate later.
author: Ray C.

description:
I have to admit to being perplexed by the lukewarm and negative reviews here...

Enjoyed dinner here with a friend on a Friday night and we were totally impressed. Being on The Presidio is an experience in and of itself - a unique "city" within San Francisco. The relative solitude of The Presidio's main parade ground adds to the ambience of eating in The Commissary with its high ceilings and comfortably spaced tables. The food was elegant - both to taste and in presentation. The staff were extra courteous and real pros. As a starter the cauliflower soup was one of the best vegetable soups I've ever had, and our fish entrée (wrapped in a Spanish ham or bacon) was incredible.

Ambience, food, service - highly recommended, a unique dining experience in San Francisco.
author: Arthur S.

description: Amazing place. Service was excellent. I suggest sitting by the bar because it is nice to enjoy your meal and watch the chefs in action! My gfs and I tried practically every tapa they had and were stuffed (shared between 3 people). My favorites: 1) Bomba queso (not too sure of the name but they're little fried cheese balls whose flavors literally cause a party in your mouth!!!!) 2) Apple Salad? again...so yummy, the thin slices of Apple w/ a light acidic sauce n the cheese just go so well together; 3) civiche (fish was really fresh and melted in your mouth) Everything was just so good! Other tapas we had that were also yummy were octopus, cauliflower, and a chickpea type of pancake. I really wish we had room for the main entrees but since we didn't, one day I'll be back! As for desserts...I honestly wish I liked goat cheese because they're cheesecake is rated as one of the best. Unfortunately it wasn't to my liking because I'm just not a goat cheese type of person. The rice pudding, however, was delicious!!!!!
author: Cheryl V.

description:
Food was terribly underwhelming and mostly over cooked. Temps were off on virtually all dishes. The tuna was a disaster. Most of the dishes are expected. Nothing mind blowing or innovative. I'm sure it will improve but I wasn't impressed. 

The drinks were good. 

Worst was the taxi situation. They could not secure a cab for us and left is stranded for an hour trying to secure a cab.
author: Gregory H.

description:
The Commissary does not have a very inviting atmosphere for dates,  as has been mentioned. There are only two tables for two. The other options are communal tables,  the bar or a bar overlooking the kitchen.  
The food is very disappointing,  lacking in flavor and not as interesting as one would expect of tapas.
Perhaps they are working out the menu and it will improve.
Tracy needs a new manager and a better executed menu.
author: mi m.

description:
Chic space, fun vibe, great service, and inspired food. I love meals where I can taste the chef's artistic experimentation, where the dishes are presented like works of art. I love crafting the perfect bite from those meals, knowing a lot of thought went into designing the right complimentary flavors. Like the gorgeous halibut: perfectly cooked and with a crisped skin, a subtle flavor with some flake and some crisp that was complimented by the crunch of beans, some acidity & sweetness from slow-roasted cherry tomatos, and moistened by a decadent, rich, savory broth. Washed down with their Albarino (their wine list has some great Spanish finds), every bite was bliss. My dinner companions had the chicken (which was roasted so perfectly that every bite, even of breast, was juicy, and with just a hint of dates and almonds), and the steak (an ideal medium-rare). The nectarine-plum sorbet was like Summer in a Glass Bowl, and the ice cream sandwich was very good, though the cookie was a bit too hard for one's fork to dig easily into.
The reason it gets 4 stars and not 5 is for price--for the portions, the prices are pretty steep. Everyone's entree was appetizer-sized, and yet the cheapest was $27. The expensive appetizers are minuscule, and the sorbet is two, tablespoon-sized scoops. You even have to pay $5 for bread. I get that they're in an expensive space and that their food is art, but I think at this early point--before they've really established their reputation--they need to be careful of pricing out some of the very customers they wish to target. Don't forget, Commissary, that most San Franciscans right now are emptying their wallets on rent--when we have two pennies to rub together we'd rather a full belly and some free bread.
author: Ali M.

description:
I'm was initially leaning towards 3.5 Stars. Largely because it's opening week and giving them the benefit of the doubt I moved up.

I have to start by saying first, I'm a little biased because I have eaten Spanish food pretty regularly. Additionally, I have a older child who lived in Spain and pointed things out that probably didn't look obvious. Secondly, this review is based off of The Commissary only being open about a week. First and foremost, the restaurant is very open and feels very comfortable. I like the soft leather seats, matching wooden tables following the theme of a old style army mess hall. We had 6 o'clock reservations. Arrived 15 minutes early, but were seated promptly.The host said it was okay as there were seats available. I noticed that the main dinning area was half full. Later, we noticed that the majority of the diners were sitting at the Kitchen table. Later it started filling up. Waiter arrived shortly with food and drink menus. He was very pleasant and informative.We went ahead with drink orders. We ordered  a glass of Finca Sandaval, a glass of Dos Tiempos,  a cocktail, a 24TH & YORK and Sangria. For my taste the Sandaval was the best of the two wines. The cocktail was a tequila blanco, orange, lime, agave, cayenne salt drink. According to my fellow guest, it was just okay. As for the Sangria, unfortunately, it was not ready and had to wait 15 minutes. In the end, didn't have much of an infused fruit flavor that Sangria is known for. I recommend they probably should make sure a batch is ready to go at all times.
Since, we all wanted to try as much of the menu, we ordered family style and shared all the food Items. We had the crispy spring potatoes, romesco sauce, albondigas, little gems, manchego, quince vinaigrette, almonds salad and a artichoke salad (not listed on online menu). They ended up sending us the anchovies, vinegar and salt cured also on the house (nice touch). I think the toasted sour dough make it. Came here to try the paella. Saddly, they took it off the menu because it wasn't quite what they wanted to serve. We were out of luck on that one. So, the  entrees were new york steak, mojo verde, salt roasted potatoes, striped bass, clams, toasted almond-garlic picada and lamb sausage. Total of three entrees. For dessert, the churros with chocolate. Now my review. Pretty mixed. I think the Potatos in romesca needs more. Additionally, I've seen these in wedges rather than cubes. The albondigas were a little dry for my taste. Just Okay. Both the Salads were good. The Little Gems can probably add more vinaigrette. All the main course entree's were very good. We devoured all of the down. Only nit picky thing would be presentation. Bass needs to be in a bigger plate. Need to see ingredients. The Steak with potatoes was presented off to one side and not at center of plate. As for the Lamb Sausage, we think it needs more greens.
From there it went a little south. We sat around for close to a half our....I think GM noticed it was taking to long so he apologizing sent a glass of pedro ximenez, rum. Waiter finally came over and took our Dessert order. It was almost a disaster. Churros and Chocolate, sent back twice because too doughy at center. Churros are not Doughy!  On third time, GM sent over Saffron Vanilla Ice cream which was very good to replace it. Overall, good food experience. Need to add more Spanish Options (ie. Olives, Chesses, tapas), Now the downside. Hopefully this gets fixed. Details, details, Details...Need more Wait Staff. We counted maybe two people taking orders for main area. Still looked like they were learning everything. One person bringing out food. Took too long for wait staff to come clear dishes and glasses. .......as a side note, no lights on outside bathroom areas in evening. Hope to be back in a few months.
author: J G.

description:
Gorgeous San Francisco day compelled me to take a walk through The Presidio and stop for a late lunch bite at The Commissary. Sat outside on the front porch but the inside space looked comfortable and open.  Service welcoming and attentive. Tried the Serrano ham Bocadillo served with a too large mound of fresh arugula salad. While everything tasted ok, overall the presentation and dish seemed a bit lackluster.  A glass of the Rojo Sangria hit the spot, refreshing and delish. 

May try it again for lunch or dinner. Usually enjoy Jardiniere so have high hopes.
author: Nancy D.

description:
The pork entree I ordered was fantastic but it was the only highlight of the night. The pork itself wasnt great- it had a really sexy crisp on the outside from the roast but the flavor was meh- was made up by how awesome their barley was along with the carrots they had on the dish. The roast chicken my wife ordered was pedestrian. To yea the plate was staged nicely but for $27 it wasnt worth it. Small portion and dry. The liver mousse on the bread that came with the chicken was also unpalatable. 
Overall- decent- not great. Won't be jumping to return. The cocktails were off, the food was hit or miss.
author: Nick D.

description: We found a high top by the bar. Several servers walked by without greeting us. After ten minutes we had to go ask for a drink menu at the bar. Several minutes later a server said "I'm yours " and kept going. Five minutes after that we started to get up to leave and he arrived. He held his hands up in the air saying, "What do you want?" When I told him that we had been waiting 15 minutes, he said that was untrue.   I said that I would like a Cosmo and he told me they don't make them. Really? They have a full bar. Who doesn't make Cosmos?  Anyway, rude and inattentive staff. Big disappointment!
author: Johanna H.

description: Food was good, just not for the price. Definitely would not recommend for groups because they really take advantage of you with an 'admin' fee plus an even more over-priced menu.
author: Michael N.

description:
This was not our first choice of restaurants, but my wife did not want any asian-influences in our restaruant selection.  So my son (a foodie in training) and I decided on the Commissary, which seemed to have a promising menu.  We were familiar with the reputation of the chefs, and Wow!  They did not disappoint.  There was not a bad dish on this menu.  The preparations were intricate and sophisticated, and we had soooo many "this is crazy" moments.

Our favorites: Cuttlefish, Octopus and (of all things) roast chicken.  These were spectacular, but the others were nutty good too.  Ex:
- asparagas salad - had an amazingly complex creamy avocado smear, I don't know what's in it but you just wanted to savor it.  The dressing was a smoky vinagrette, surprising yet fresh.
- Salt Cod Fritters - salty, crunchy, and surprisingly light with a lighter bready texture - unlike a heavy fritter. Perfectly paired with a lemon Aoli.
- Cuttlefish - super tender but served with arroz verde made from aborio rice with (I think) parsley, cilantro, mint - such a warm and well rounded softness to the flavor, a perfect compliment.

We had the jamon wrapped trout (super), the pork loin (amazing spanish spices and an incredible farro base) and the roast chicken- This is not your normal roast chicken, the preparation is outstanding- seems to be some sort of a sherry based brine or glaze..super tender, moist and succulant.

I can go on forever, but if you have to try it yourself.  There is no way words can serve the food justice.
author: anthony l.

description: The Commissary is such a treat! Beautiful setting in the Presidio and easy to get to despite being a little hidden away in the park. The food is great - every dish has an interesting spin on simple ingredients. Bone marrow was delicious, kale salad with goat cheese and blackberries also so flavorful, spanish style octopus was my favorite and the bombos (little cheese fritters with honey and truffle) are addictive! The dining room is warm and inviting and the staff were friendly and knowledgable. The whole vibe is one of people having a lovely time with great food :) Will definitely go back when in San Francisco - don't be put off by the location in fact the location makes dinner even more special...
author: Barbara L.

description:
Delicious food and fantastic people. We dropped in for a late lunch after flying up from LA. Since we were staying at the Inn at the Presidio, the Commissary was just a short walk. There are plenty of seating options outside and inside, we opted for eating at the kitchen bar so we could watch the talented chefs do their thing! Everything we tried was amazing, including the potato pancake dish, cauliflower dish, the burger and fries, and the Rose that accompanied our meal! Only disappointed we couldn't eat there for dinner. 
Definitely check it out!
author: Suzie M.

description: Limited menu, sorry choice of deserts.  Service is inattentive.  Heavy have with the salt on most dishes.  Not a be back place.
author: Russ H.

description:
Service:  Good.  Our waitress and bus person were great, but they were clearly understaffed or just disorganized (management).  Everything kind of fell apart toward the end of the meal (asking for things repeatedly...)

Food:  
Bussell sprouts - really good!
Crispy new potatoes - ok
Salt cod fritters -ok
Sweet pea and ham croquetas - good
Octopus - really good!
Trout - ok, kind of dry on top, so eat the bottom first
author: Juliana L.

description: Very disappointed dinner. The location is wonderful but other than that, it was a big disappointment from appetizer to dessert. For the appetizer, we fried the fritters and the stone fruit with Serrano ham. Nothing to brat about. Tried the NY steak, halibut and chicken for entree. The chicken is the best but even that is not impressive enough to make up for the steak. It was cooked right at medium rare but the meat has no taste. Halibut was ok. Dessert was basically a piece of cinnamon bread with berries. Definitely not worth the money.
author: Mimi L.

description: If you enjoy soul-less poorly conceived and executed food in bizarrely tiny portions, an unsettling atmosphere and design that is a cross between a Livermore model home and a Restoration Hardware outlet, understaffed and depressing service, and waiting a while for all of it; I couldn't recommend this nightmare of a restaurant enough.  This is the worst cost-to-pleasure ratio restaurant experience I can remember having over the past few years.  On the plus side, because the portions were so small, my dining companions and I were able to have a second full dinner at A16 afterward, and were mostly able to wash the taste of the Commissary out our literal and figurative mouths.
author: Andrew G.

description: The food is delicious but the service needs work.  We arrived at 6:45 and did not leave until 9:30.  We waited a long time for cocktails and then our food, but everything was really tasty.  The history of the building and location are very interesting.  Perhaps some of the many front door greeters could become servers or bartenders to improve the slow service.
author: K C.

description:
Overall experience was superb! Welcoming staff, excellent service, tasty and well executed plates. We started with Churros and chocolate sauce and the GM brought us some 23 yr old port to enjoy with it (and several other savory starters). He was impressed by our style.

Atmosphere offers something for everyone. An open, spacious and uncluttered main dining room with bar area offers a sophisticated dining experience. Or you can sit at the Chef's counter, which is more lively and interactive, and watch the magic happen.

We did not expect everything to be seamless in the first week. Any missteps were quickly remedied with sincere effort.

My one suggestions is serve the Striped Sea Bass and a few other dishes on a larger plate. The food was a little crowded and I wanted a spot to put sides and bread (which was warm, crusty and delicious).

And...we drove up and parked in front which in SF is unheard of. Parking ample and super easy. Nice when you are wearing heals!

Will definitely be returning soon and looking for a spot at the Chef's counter!
author: Cari G.

description: Had a fun time at The Commisary last night, all 4 of us enjoyed our dinners.  Shared small plates to start, loved the salt cod fritters and the ham and pea croquettes.  My lamb and eggplant was so delicious.  The others enjoyed the tuna dish and the steak dish.  The atmosphere is fun, next time I want to sit at the bar by the kitchen.  Great new spot in the Presidio.  A fun place to take friends from out of town.
author: Carole W.

description: The space is beautiful, but the service is inconsistent and the menu is small with not a whole lot of variation from week to week.  Some of the things on the menu I like a lot, other things are ok.  I would give this place 3 stars but I had high expectations for this place.  It's in a great location and could be a great after work hang out spot if they catered to that crowd.
author: Jay K.

description:
A terribly disappointing experience last night.  Service was a real problem.  Took almost 10 minutes for someone to come to the table after our party of 4 was seated.  Then took almost another 10 minutes for our server to inform us that they were out of the wine we ordered.  Appetizers came out in a timely manner, then 30-40 min. for our entrees to follow after the appetizer dishes were cleared.  Then compounded by our side dish arriving 3/4 of the way into the meal. Desserts were similarly delayed.  All in all, a three+ hour meal (not by our choice).  We watched tables on either side of us arrive later and leave before us.   Our server never apologized or informed us for the reason behind the delay until I asked him later in the meal and he told us  that the kitchen was not able to handle the prime-time reservation period (7-7:30) when 12 tables were full (then why accept all reservations int the first place, why not stagger better?).   

Now to the food- appetizers were excellent (lamb meatballs, sourdough bread, cheese balls) - entrees were ok (chicken, steak and sole).  No wow factor. 

One very positive note: The bartender was outstanding-  Excellent mixologist!   Would definitely come here for a drink (only)  in the future.

Considering the "pedigree" of this restaurant, I was expecting much better.   If you want a truly classic Traci Des Jardins experience do not come here, rather go to her eponymous restaurant Jardiniere, for a truly memorable meal.
author: Michael K.

description:
The food is very good here.  Codfish fritters and cuttlefish were excellent and the trout wrapped in Iberian ham was a great idea and well executed. Green tomato salad good but not as interesting as expected. 
The space is open and the hard surfaces make for a noisy main room. You can eat at the bar surrounding the cooking area in the back room and cut down the noise.
As others have noted this is an easy restaurant to get too with ample parking and a great venue. The staff is cheerful and still learning as the pacing was choppy, but the food is worth it. If you go easy on drinks and wine the bill is not too bad either.
author: Phil S.

description: Morning of riding bikes brought us into the Presidio, we stumbled across the  Commisary and had lunch. GREAT FOOD,and drinks, small but good menu. friendly and good service. We sat at the chefs counter and loved it . Kevin, the chef was so cool and gave us a few bites of things to try. Way cool place!
author: Jeff N.

description:
We went to the Commissary last night with a party of 12 and had an absolutely amazing experience. The staff was so kind and attentive and the food was diverse and excellent. Everyone ordered something different and raved about each item. I had the Hamon wrapped trout which had amazing flavor and was on top of a delicious sauce and bed of garden vegetables and mushrooms. The environment was a very cool combination of modern improvements and the original mess hall architecture left over from the old military base. 

This dinner was the first event to kick off our wedding weekend here at the Presidio, all of our friends and family are staying at the Presidio Inn and enjoying the beautiful environment and the easy access right into the city. Although who would want to leave this natural sanctuary?

Check it out, it's an amazing spot!
author: Gene M.

description:
Our first visit to Commisary...we will be back.
Inventive as well as excellent is a difficult balance to maintain. Something as simple as corn, when grilled, rolled in granulated cheese sprinkled with espellete, makes it sublime. The octopus, vegetable  galette and trout on a bed of vegetables were all wonderfully prepared and seasoned.
This is not a fussy place...only wonderful!
Share plates! The more the merrier!
author: Philip W.

description:
Busy place, reserve in advance.

We sat at the chefs bar. Food was delicious, highly recommend the monterey squid (if on menu). Efficient service. Pricey cocktails, lacks wow.
author: Philip T.

description: Delicious.  DELICIOUS.  We sat at the Chef's Counter and had a blast.  The salad was ridiculously fresh and tasty.  The beef in the burger was terrific - forgot how good burgers could be.  The chicken and kale dish was terrific, not soggy or tasteless like I sometimes get when I order kale.  Good portions.
author: Laura Jane B.

description:
When I've been to the Commissary the first time I was thrilled. Great food and service. We were so happy that we took our friends here to show our new discovery.

BUT...unfortunately it was a disaster. The second time was really bad. It started with a very unmotivated waiter. He was really strange and arrogant. And he let us wait for our drink order forever (the drinks came after the appetizers, we approx waited 30 minutes).

Some of the appetizers we had the last time were suddenly only mini portions. The taste was not the same, in fact one was very bland and the other one was overcooked. 

They brought us the wrong main dishes so two of us had to wait another 15 minutes. There was no apology about this from the waiter. All main dishes were very disappointing. The great taste and the surprising mixes of food we had the last time was not seen in one of the dishes. 

Quick overview:
- expensive food, small portions, bland taste 
- staff seems not organized, waiter was very unfriendly

Gladly there are many other great restaurants in SF.
author: Diana B.

description: Awesome food, ambiance and staff! Sit at the counter.... that kitchen staff is working hard to create nothing but amazing plates, plus it's fun to be involved in the action. Can't wait to come back!
author: Deena R.

description:
Recently dined at The Commisary, it was as good as I wanted it to be.  

We ordered the arugala salad with peaches and ricotta - very good, nice proportions.

roasted cuttlefish, arroz verde, pistachio, squid ink- excellent my favorite of the evening (nicely seared, good flavor in the rice, pistachio add a nice nuttiness)

jamon wrapped trout, trumpet mushroom - good for me (due to licorice  flavor in sauce) /great for my husband 

lamb shoulder, farro, eggplant with date and chermoula sauce - good (i'm not a big fan of the fat that can come with lamb) 

roasted carrots on cranberry bean hummus, roasted sesame and pumkin seeds - excellent- nice balance of flavors and textures.

txchacolina- lovely effervescence to the white wine (traditional basque wine very enjoyable with fish and small dishes)

dessert - churro - great! warm, sugary, not too big -just right to end meal.

Location- lovely with plenty of parking and nice for a stroll. 
The food is good (with great sprinkled about)
the atmosphere is good -cozy, clean lines with an open kitchen so you can watch the bustle.
the staff is great and made the experience fun and inclusive.  It is very nice to discuss the food with the cooks, maitre d and the server.

This place will be my new go to neighborhood restaurant.
author: Danielle B.

description: Service was confusing and the prices were higher than expected.  Loved the interior and location.
author: Ali B.

description: I loved their octopus dish and their pork had excellent flavor. However it is too bright and open space for a relaxing dinner. Service was good. Their servers seem to know their menu very well or maybe we got lucky.
author: Ichi Y.

description:
Went with a group for a nice lunch and had a great time and great meal. We got to sit in the back room and see the chefs and they were very friendly. Chef Martin was incredibly helpful and nice. He have us some recommendations on what to order and pair with and was incredibly friendly and funny. It is nice to go to such a high quality restaurant and have ppl who are so helpful and down to earth. That experience alone was worth it, but the food was also great. 

The home made pate was a treat as well as the tuna salads and octupus. Great mixture of rich flavors, that are not too heavy and go well together. 

Also, the venue is really nice. The natural light and historical setting are fun and different. Great to walk around the presidio after the meal.

Great restaurant and chef Martin is the man!
author: Dan K.

description:
Sat at the chef's table and watched how the chef prepared each meal, tasting it to make sure it was perfect before it was sent out. Unfortunately, he used pretty much every cooking utensil at his disposal to taste with, which he returned to his utensil holder without washing. He even used a small spatula to spread some tapenade on toast that he previously used to taste a dish with by placing the entire spatula in his mouth. Not sure if this is industry standard, but I personally liken it to spitting in a dish. I have no problem with a chef tasting my dish, but please use a new spoon each time!! I don't want your hep-a, b or c please.

Also, plates were dirty, and service was slow, but this is most probably due to management understaffing the place.

Food overall was good, but not great. Tuna was overdone. Brussels sprouts were awesome. Didn't get to try the cauliflower since it was covered in chef spit.

To sum up, it's commiserations for the ignorant at the commissary.
author: Josh G.

description: We first came here a year or so ago when it opened and were underwhelmed. But no longer! Just had an absolutely wonderful experience for drinks and dinner! Lisa, the bartender, with whom we enjoyed some time during the pre-dinner calm was knowledgeable about wine and very friendly. Our server, Rosaria, could not have been more attentive. The floor manager also  checked in on our meal. So, service has really come together and is top notch. The menu options are diverse and creative without being fussy. The food was outstanding - among which the steak was cooked perfectly, and a lamb sausage starter that we can't wait to go back and have again. I love the clean, modern yet warm decor, and being in the Presidio offers a nice change from the bustle of the city. If you too had a so-so experience here before, I recommend giving it another shot. 5 stars!
author: Rita G.

description: If Traci Des Jardins managed a baseball team, the World Series trophy would never leave the City. We dined on a Tuesday night; seating options were patio or inside at the small tables, bar counter, communal tables or the kitchen counter. Our server Delis, was knowledgeable, friendly and like the rest of the staff we interacted with, very attentive. The Spanish-themed menu works well; such attention to detail in taste and presentation from hand-crafted cocktails to the amazing appetizers and entrees (salt cod fritters, roasted chicken, halibut) and desserts (torrijas, double choc ice cream sandwich). The ambience is comfortable whether it's a casual or special dining experience.
author: Chris E.

description: Excellent Top Notch Restaurant!!! The Chef's are Fantastic!!! They somehow can cook everything to absolute Perfection not to mention the seasoning of the Dishes!  The Drinks are to Die For!  I've eaten there twice! Beautiful & Historic Building with easy Parking.
author: Sparky W.

description: A little disappointing.  My gf had the fish and I had this potato vegetarian thing.  I saw a pic of the veg dish and it looked completely different then what came out.  And the taste was lack lustre, basically scalloped potatoes I could've made on my own.  We may have shared a salad, but nothing was memorable about this meal.  Sorry but at least I tried!
author: Meredith K.

description:
My husband and I went here on a Tuesday night. It was a random date night since I went into a client office located in the same building as his office. It was easy to get a reservation at 6pm on a Tuesday. Easy parking in the Presidio. 

You want to know about the food. It was bland. Service was poor. We ordered:

* cauliflower soup - good smooth texture. No seasoning. Have you heard of salt and pepper? The basics would be fine. We don't expect a lot of seasoning but a little something would be nice. 

* octopus - this was better than the soup. Better seasoning. 

* bread basket - my husband asked several times for the server for bread and asked for it to be brought out with the appetizers. It came at the end. 

* roasted chicken - this was my  husband's dish. He was highly disappointed. Again, bland. I could make a better roasted chicken with just a little but of herbs and salt and pepper. Not hard to just use some basic items to add flavor. 

* jamon wrapped trout - this was ok. It had some seasoning but the flavor mix was lost with all the mushrooms on the plate. I love mushrooms but when they are all over your plate and making it drown the fish, i lose sight of what i ordered and flavor. The jamon was extremely crispy and hard to cut and eat with the fish in each bite. 

Service was poor. Again, when you ask for something, it would be good to deliver it. 

Our list says....do not return.
author: Susan L.

description:
Overall very good.  Made reservations via Yelp's SeatMe and it went very smooth.  Cool decor and atmosphere.  Location is amazing, lots of things to do in the Presidio, great place for the family, we went and took an hour long walk in Crissy field beforehand.  

We went to The Commissary on a Friday night and it was fairly busy.  We took our infant daughter with us and they were very accommodating towards our needs, the staff and the service were excellent.

As for the food, in general it was good but certain dishes were just ok and may be too expensive.  The best things we had were the Cuttlefish and the Cod Fritters.  Those 2 dishes are an absolute must order!  The Cod fritters melts in your mouth and the taste is not very fishy.  The Jamon wrapped Trout was very delicious and tender and the side dish of Corn (with shaved Cornnuts!) in aioli was yummy, the trumpet mushrooms were pretty good too.  We had the Churros for dessert.
