The Pork meatballs were nothing too special ($12 for 4 small meatballs) (I couldn't help but to think to myself this dish was missing something).  Potato appetizers were also very meh, and kind of bland.  The Lamb shoulders was ok but didn't stand out too much.  

Again, I found the place to be charming and the staff service were excellent.  Some things on the menu could use a bit of improvement but the place is still very new so it could be they are still working out the kinks.  I would definitely come back again soon.

Traci has a winner here.

*Edit*

We were seated at our own table.  The communal tables were in a different room.
author: Kitai P.

description: I recently had dinner here with my friends from out of town. We had a surprise 4 yr old guest at dinner. They did not flinch and were so accommodating for our surprise guest. The service was excellent, from the restaurant manager to wait staff, they were uber friendly and helpful. I had a party of 8 and was sat right away with our table ready. The two dishes that I loved (recommended) Octopus (tapas) and Chicken (entree) melted in my mouth. There was a little snafu with one of the steak entrees, but they fixed it right away and returned it cooked perfect.  The manager came by often to check on us and the wait staff were attentive to our needs. I would definitely come back and try the chef's table in the kitchen.
author: Lily H.

description: The food is marginal, the service is poor, and the drinks are tiny and expensive, but who cares, I like to try new restaurants.  The real reason I'm writing this review is to CAUTION other diners to check their credit card statements and reconcile their dinner check. The Commissary was apparently unhappy with my 15%, or $60 tip, so they added on an additional $92 tip.  What's even more frustrating is that I've had to call the restaurant 4 times in the last week and it's still not resolved.
author: Ana M.

description: I had the pleasure of dining at The Commissary last Saturday the 16th.   It was my first time at this great restaurant.   Service was warm and prompt.    I ate at the dining room bar not realizing dining was available at kitchen counter where all the action is - next time I go I'll be sure to eat there!   I had the smoked trout salad - it's something that you'll savor with every bite.   I also had the blistered shishito peppers and the fried cheese with black truffle honey (bombas de queso).   Everything was so rich and delicious that I was fully satiated by the starters alone.    I had to take my chickpea galeta to go and I had no room for desert.  Great place for one dining alone.
author: Josie R.

description: Great place, definitely sit in the back with the kitchen  staff, very friendly, overall great service and food. Will be back.
author: Ryan G.

description: Very mediocre. Everything was over spiced. Portions small and overpriced. $32 for a piece of trout smaller than the credit card I reluctantly plunked down for this $60 dinner (without wine or tip). Skip it.
author: Kent R.

description: This is indeed a terrific place to dine. From the setting in the Presidio to the food and service, this place easily rates 5 stars. Gorgeous!
author: Michael B.

description: Two stars for having a restaurant in a beautiful location, yummy sangria, and friendly servers. Minus three stars for food that is just, well, not that great. I'm hoping they are still figuring out their menu since they are new, but we were not impressed. We had two starters (butternut squash and salted cod) that were both deep fried. (Deep frying is basically cheating, of course if'll taste good). The little gem salad was boring, though my brother and dad enjoyed their mushroom salad. I had the chickpea gallete, which was essentially a fried chickpea latke. Again, fried. The dishes in general seemed to be missing that- oh wow that tastes so good! factor. Generally a pleasant dinner, but I had high expectations and was disappointed, so I won't be back any time soon.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Pretty disappointing. I was expecting great things given the Chef and the amazing Presidio location and it fell short across the board. 

The decor was minimalist, but boring. There wasn't much of the character you see with other renovated Presidio buildings. Everything was neutral in color, placement of the tables was boring. Boring is their theme. 

My husband and I sat at the bar for dinner since they didn't have any open tables. That's great as we like eating at bars, usually. The bar at the Commissary is ...yep, boring. The bartenders were having a seemingly bad night. Very busy, the servers were yelling at them, they didn't have time to service their guests at the bar. It was not pleasant to observe.

The food was not great. Ordered the calamari, the peach salad and the NY steak. The calamari flavor was nice but it had some weird coating on it so it had an off texture. The peach salad, $14 i believe, was ugly and way too sweet. The dish didn't work. The steak was very good and would recommend that.

Overall, the service we received was very lackluster, the food was sub-par given the chef and the prices, and the interior was stark and uninviting. I will definitely not go back and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else.
author: Heather W.

description:
We ate lunch there today after taking the Presidio tour.  The food is overpriced, with very ungenerous portions.  Although it tasted pretty good - nothing special - we both left hungry.  I had the clams in chorizo broth and they ended up costing a dollar apiece.  My lunch partner had the basque style chicken -- two skinny drumsticks and some potatoes.  Each entree was $14 and neither came with any kind of salad or other green vegetable.  I got a couple of very thin slices of bread with the clams.  The people at other tables who had ordered salads apparently had to specially order (and pay for?) bread to go with them.  Our waitperson had trouble getting our bill right, and initially overcharged me $2 for the clams.  They seem very overstaffed.  I hope they will either serve more food for the money, or drop their prices.  Otherwise, I don't predict a rosy future.  We certainly won't go back.
We heard on the tour that the same executive chef will be in charge of Arguello, the restaurant opening soon in the Officers Club.  All I can say is, I hope the food there is more special and better priced.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
We had a great dinner at this restaurant(pork braised in salsa, kale salad, roasted squash finishing with the quince, almond tart.) so I can't say enough about the food. It was fabulous. 
Unfortunately, the spotty service seriously affected our experience. The host had to ask 3x for my name  (it was under the res), this was while we waited and waited and waited for our table. The same spaced out service continued with our wait-person, who didn't show up at our table for a good ten minutes and once drink orders were taken, disappeared for another ten. Not good. 
It was befuddling as tons wait people ( in what looked like girl scout uniforms, rethink thise please !) were running frantically all over the place but unable to make eye contact with us once ! 

Hopefully a bit more  staff training will correct this.
author: anita w.

description:
I took my husband here for his birthday. On the way out, I asked if he would ever go there again, and he said "no," which was disappointing for a special occasion.

There's a lot right about The Commissary. It's fun to have a location in an historic building in the Presidio, the design is lovely, and we enjoyed eating at the bar sitting around the kitchen. The cooks were amiable and gave us recommendations.

The food didn't live up to my expectations, however, particularly given Traci des Jardin's involvement. What did she do, walk through the kitchen once? There wasn't anything wrong with it, but it was like food by committee, not the expression of a chef's vision or passion. Everything was just a little off, like the chef just couldn't be bothered. 
The gazpacho was good, but just a tad acidic even for people who love acid.
The "little gem" salad was romaine, and boring.
The much-haralded octopus was fine, but fine the way any Spanish tapas bar anywhere makes it.
My pork was overcooked.
The NY steak was not medium rare, as it was supposed to be, but barely pink.
The brussels sprouts were good; much better at SPQR.
The chocolate dessert was your basic molten chocolate dessert; good, no big deal.
The ricotta cheesecake with fig was good, but sprinkled with granola, which was like, um, pass the milk.

My biggest complaint was the wine glasses, which were like short little ramekins, and surely an indication of how no chef is presiding here. Why in the world would you serve good wine in a squat little glass where all the bouquet escapes? Half of the experience of the wine is the aroma, which is why--duh--people have been serving wine in rounded glasses since the Greeks. You want to capture the aroma. Big wine, bigger glass. I asked for a real wine glass because I refused to throw money away on an expensive bottle of wine and a little ramekin. You might as well drink it out of styrofoam.

So: Someone is not paying attention to actual TASTE here. We're a town of foodies. You can't put this over on us. Up your game or go home. Far, far better to go to the Presidio Social Club, with a similar atmosphere, and simple food that has heart.
author: Laura F.

description:
The location and decor was very nice and well put together.

The food was very bad. The lamb tasted disgusting, the padron peppers lacked seasoning and the tuna was over cooked. BUT The corn was amazing.

The service was also very poor. We had to ask for water three times before we got it. We had to wait for utensils and had to ask for them twice when food was served. The waiter broke the cork in the wine and was the wine was completely opposite in how he described it (though the wine was quite good).

I was hoping for so much more and was very let down.
author: Sean S.

description: Easily one of my favorite new restaurants in the Bay Area. I was already a big fan of Jardiniere, so I came in expecting the food to be solid, and it was. The jamon wrapped trout was one of the best dishes I have had in quite some time. Other gems included the chicken with dates, salt cod fritters and all of our drinks. Couple the great stuff that is going on in the kitchen with an awesome location and space. Only thing that wasn't solid was the service. Our hostess was rude and wait staff had to ask our drink and appetizer order a few times. We'll definitely be back.
author: Steven W.

description: Beyond being 100% worth it, awesome, delicious, fun, and delightful.... the only helpful tidbit I can help with is buffering against this reality:  If you book at Open Table or make a reservation, you are still 100% liable and likely to end up at a communal table, because "that is how commissary dining used to be".  If you are the type that followed Bauer's conversation about communal tables, etc, or have issues with them, save this restaurant a negative review by choosing a different spot.  Or at least reference that you don't want to be sat at a communal table in your reservation. Hope this helps!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Well this place was recommended to me by my neighbor so i was expecting good food.
After calling three or four times to make a reservation and leaving a message as directed i received no call back. We decided to walk over there and were told it would be a 20 minute wait. They said their phone system had not been working. We ordered drinks. Hmmm a $6 beer in a can and a $10 mixed drink that contained as much as most bartenders spill when they make a real drink...An hour and a half later we were still waiting! We paid for our two rounds of drinks and ordered Thai food as we walked home. P.S The Thai food for 3 was less than the drinks! Not sure how my neighbor got food here but good for him!
author: Dave X.

description:
We arrived about 6:30 and were seated at the counter overlooking the desert chef station!  What a great view point of the deserts and kitchen operations!

The lamb and chicken dishes were great!  The chic peas and salad creative and tasty.

Fir desert we had the cookie with olive oil ice cream.... A winner.

We asked for our left overs to be boxed but they ever made it to us.  Service despite being at the counter was sporadic. Water went long periods without refills.

I would come back.... Seems $$$$
author: Richard L.

description:
Walked in on a Sat., everyone  very nice but inexperienced, unpolished waitstaff.  We ordered cosmos and nobody knew how to make them. They appear too cheap for a bartender and their inability to make the cocktails on their special cocktail menu slows the food service down, despite their layers of kitchen expediters that run around.  

We ordered right away, asked for bread (you only get it on request), and did not receive it until we were into our meal with the  excuse that they were warming it up. The bread is very good.Menu selections:chicken was tasty, lamb cut was tasty, but fatty, chewy and $24. You decide. Veggies were tasty but soaked. 

Wines by the glass start around $9-$16. They are not generous with their pours. When you are marking up table wines 200-300%, that is not OK.

We are major foodies. We have eaten in so many fab SF & SF area restaurants. It is a pity that this fabulous exec chef has gotten off to a slow start in this wonderful location. There is potential here because of the setting and the flavors. However, there is a lot of improvement required. The service needs some serious realignment and training.  The flavors are good but QC is in dire need of attention out the door and dish conceptualization. And for God's sake, hire a bartender.
author: jj c.

description: The food is amazing. The service was atrocious. Cocktails are forgettable. The manager went to fix our bill and there was a slew of items that we never ordered. We ordered multiple items at the same time. Our server never asked if we wanted them served at the same time or not. It didn't matter much because we still never reviewed our main dishes after bring here over an hour. Again, the food is great, if you can get it. There are too many good places in SF to waste your time here.
author: Lily P.

description:
We came many times and consistenly great food and service.

On a nice day you can eat outside.
author: Alex D.

description:
I hesitate writing a review during opening week but I do want to provide the folks at The Commissary some feedback on my dining experience last night.

Waiting 20 minutes for a drink, while seated, isn't going to please anyone. Make a better first impression.

What lacked from my meal was an attention to preparation and focus on ingredients. Be more knowledgeable about what you're putting on the table.

Elevate your wine list - it's San Francisco!
author: Peter I.

description: We stopped in for a drink while waiting for our son to get out of a dance class.  No atmosphere, horrible lighting and needlessly expensive drink.  $13 for a half glass of Spanish wine - in a glass that looked more like a ramekin or a petri dish.  Do not predict this place lasting long in foodie SF.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Heard and read a lot about this place, so finally giving it a shot.  Wine list is very impressive with its selection of Spanish and notable CA vintages.  Specialty cocktails worth exploring...I found the Buffalo Soldier quite tasty and a nice alternative to my frequent Manhattan.  Bar seating around the kitchen is delightful.  Salt cod fritters were a nice change of pace, but the pancetta wrapped trout was awesome.  I may never eat trout prepared differently again!
author: Howard B.

description:
I was surprised it wasn't full on a Saturday night, and I was also a little surprised at the setting since it literally is right inside the presidio.  We were able to park right in front with plenty of free spots available after 6pm. 

We got a seat at the bar with a direct view of the mixology, but then we realized there's a chef's table in the back with a direct view into the actual kitchen.

Drinks: 
- Sand and fog: I like that you can smell the fragrant eucalyptus and the lime leaf they top
- Wet mutt: I like grapefruit bitters, sea salt, and gin, so this was a good drink got me, but the grapefruit was subtle 
- 24th and York: mezcal, agave, cayenne salt. This needed more cayenne and something to give it a little more depth - maybe some citrus juice like grapefruit?
- A kiss and a promise: rye, lime, egg white. This was simple and light, a good drink to start with

We started with house bread which was served with a very green olive oil and sea salt. 

Food:
- Salt cod fritters: smooth potato and salted cod, fried nicely, and the grilled lemon squeezed over the top really made this dish 
- Roasted padron peppers: standard, but beware of the larger ones because the seeds inside are still really spicy!
- Ham and pea croqueta: probably my favorite dish. I was in the mood for fried food tonight. Initially it was just ok - you could taste the freshness of the peas inside, but then I realized adding some sea salt to it really brought out a ton more flavor (not just saltiness) and made the dish much better 
- Roasted cuttlefish: I liked the arroz verde and the squid ink, but I expected the cuttlefish to be more charred - it was essentially all white still, and I was looking for a more roasted flavor and appearance 
- Mackerel: with a cucumber, fennel, chickpea salad.  The salad made it taste healthy, but the mackerel didn't stand out 
- Corn: server on a cob, roasted, covered with cheese and quico (like corn nuts). The butter was a little overpowering for me and actually masked the corn's sweetness 

Dessert: 
- I really liked my soy cafe au lait
- Almond cake with tomato and plum caramel and almond milk ice cream: the olive oil almond cake was surprisingly light. The tomato part was interesting, but I didn't really like it; the plum was really good, though 

I know they just opened a few weeks ago, but I was expecting service to run a little more smoothly at the bar. We weren't offered house sparkling water, we had to keep asking for water, and they kept trying to take our menus away when we wanted more drinks.  Also, the food didn't blow me away.  The setting is unique, and I like the space inside, but I'm not sure I'll be back.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
I have visited this restaurant three times (it is conveniently located in the Presidio where I work.)  On all three occasions the food was just ok and the service was...well...slow and somewhat indifferent, with the exception of front of the house.  

On my first visit I tried the burger and it was over cooked and dried out.  On my second visit I tried the bean salad and it was over dressed + no bread offered at the table.  Yesterday, I tried the green bean salad again, plus a side of fries.  The fries arrived luke warm and a somewhat soggy - a sign the line cooks have not got their timing down.
author: Jim S.

description:
The ambiance is lovely. The black cod was delicious but honestly the size was ridiculous. 4/3 in size and served with 3 small, tiny, tiny clams. NOTHING ELSE. 

I wanted to order the sangria and didn't know if I wanted the white or red. The waitress was kind enough to ask if I would like a taste and I did. Both were delicious. I ordered the red sangria and when it came it was in a relatively small glass with MOSTLY ICE.I mentioned this to the waitress and she said that it is served from a pitcher that has lots of ice in it. It was watered down and did not taste like the one that I had sampled. My husband ordered the pork with barley which was tasty. The only food that was abundant was the bread. I really felt ripped off.
author: Lana B.

description: What beautiful ambience! Just a lovely little place that you wouldn't know was there unless you know.... The service was really good. The sangria was pretty good... Not so different from sangrias I've had elsewhere. I went with a group of six and we all got something different to eat. Everything was good, but the seafood was especially yummy. I loved the trout. The sauce it was in was like magic with a tarragon and caramel flavor. The biggest drawback was that the portions were very very small with the entrées. Next time I think I will just order Tapas and get drinks from the bar which looked very intriguing. The Meyer lemon fritters served with an espresso Anis Mascarpone, however, we're absolutely heavenly!
author: Cristen M.

description: After driving around trying to locate The Commissary - no signage visible on the street - stopped in for a cocktail.  $10 for cosmopolitan.  New trend?  Small stem - or no stems !! Not much to sip and disappointed with the small amount offered in a very small glass.  First ordered a bloody mary and there was no mix to make one.  Did enjoy the Pea and Ham Croquetas.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Lunch menu is quite good. Ordered the corn chowder soup, frisée salad, marin sun farms burger, fries w/aioli sauce and mushroom open-faced sandwich - all delicious and made from fresh ingredients locally sourced. Service is friendly, and well-designed space has a nice ambiance.
author: Anna Y.

description: The food's really good, as is the wine and sangria. The service not so much, they brought our stuff out in the wrong order.
author: Tracey W.

description: Nice place. It's a hard sell against Coqueta (though I am sure comparing is the last thing this place wants to hear), but it's lovely. Nice ambiance. Felt homey and loved the open kitchen. The squid is really good. The trout is really good. The host staff was really great. Our server seemed like he was having an off night. Also, the food runners didn't bring share plates with either one of our courses, and I had to ask twice. No big deal, but the little things, you know? The wine list was killer. Not overwhelming, not horribly expensive. I don't find multiple wines by the glass that impress me. Great job there. I know it's a tribute to Spain, but having the short wine glasses filled to the top cuts so much out of the nose and aroma of the wine. I'm a pretty traditional wine snob in that way. Perhaps points against me. But overall, it's a nice place to check out!
author: Lauren B.

description: Four of us dined last Saturday, Aug. 9th at The Commissary because we all want to try a new eating place and we were all disappointed.  For an upscale restaurant, I would expect a table cloth for each table but most of the table doesn't have table cloth except the 3 tables at the front.  One of my friend ordered steak and it's very chewy.  The plates  that they used looks so cheap, it reminds me of the dish that you can buy from a Dollar Store.  All of us are used to dining in upscale restaurants and The Commissary didn't cut at all.  I don't think it's worth coming back.
author: Fely R.

description:
After the 3rd visit to the Commissary, I am compelled to write a very negative review.
The service is truly pathetic. On our most recent visit, we had lunch at an outside table. We had to ask the waitress twice for water. When our order came, there was no cutlery so she had to go back in, then she went back again to get napkins. When our coffee was served, there were no spoons for the sugar. We had to ask 3 times for the bread (which was an extra cost).  
The food was lackluster. ..a salad with plain mashed potatoes wrapped in a tasteless steamed spinach leaf.
Given Traci des Jardins' reputation, it is hard to see why this restaurant isn't much better...and why she also operates Arguello just a few feet away which  is not particularly good either..
Seems like the Presidio could find better and more  diversified offerings for its diverse visitors.
author: Jean C.

description:
Our waiter was nice, but the host was unbelievably rude. They lost our reservation that I made only an hour beforehand. Then they tried seating us at the bar despite tables that sat empty. When we objected they finally seated us.

When I stepped out of the room momentarily the host said to my girlfriend "Next time you make a reservation specify you want a table!"  What?? What else does a reservation suggest? Did he think we were reserving two chairs?

While I'm happy seeing more businesses open in the presidio this kind of treatment is totally reprehensible.

The food was great and the atmosphere at the Commissary is very pleasant.
author: Brent S.

description: Lunch menu is limited. Service is flawed. Overall only the location and the atmosphere were worth a return. Front and back of operation need attention to detail.
author: David L.

description: Sit at the kitchen bar seats, never a dull moment. Cod Fritters were great and dessert lemon ricotta beignets ridiculously good. I will be back for sure and try to do better on my entree ordering as Tuna and shrimp dish were unwhelming. Next time steak for sure?...
author: Matt H.

description:
My husband and I loved our dinner at The Commissary. The food is stellar - it's Traci Des Jardins after all - complex but clean, beautiful presentation, and very flavorful with a Spanish inflection in honor of the Presidio's past, superb local ingredients. And unlike most restaurants where dessert is a completely different flavor profile than the food, The Commissary's desserts pair beautifully with the entrees. 

As to the space-the front room is big and comfortable with some smaller tables and several large community tables (with extremely comfortable chairs) the bar is in this room. There was clearly a lot of thought given to the noise level which is really good thanks to lots of hidden acoustic panels.  The light fixtures are from the Presidio gym and they used lots of reclaimed wood to make the tables. There's also a small commissary that sells some of the olive oils, vinegars and other products used in the menu.

The next room contains a huge open kitchen with seats at the bar on two sides. The huge windows on two sides makes this room feel really comfy - it's like being in an amazing home kitchen. 

Parking is a dream!
author: Tracy S.

description: Ate dinner with a girlfriend at one of the communal tables for 8 people last night. Great experience. Got to talking to some of the other diners at our table who recommended a few dishes and a bottle of wine they were enjoying. Brilliant. We loved the bass and the white beans, and the salt cod fritters were very well executed. These are small dishes, but between the two of us, two appetizers, a salad, an entree, and a side was plenty. Churros con chocolate was a perfect conclusion to a lovely night. Service was great. Definitely check it out.
author: Noelle F.

description:
The newest place for delicious food in the Presidio is open, and while there is some dust to brush off, I encourage you to visit sooner rather than later, because this is a good time. They are blossoming and it's something to behold.

Thanks to the Army there is this amazing place right within the city where you can throw a frisbee & not hit anything at all. Why isn't this the most popular part of our peninsula? While there is ample & cheap parking with beautiful views there's essentially no walk-in traffic & no public transit access, so your crowd is mostly car owners who have a place to park the car again when they get home (because no one wants to an end evening with a 30 minute parking hunt) or folks who use Uber. That's limiting. Personally, I'd rather drive here than downtown...

I know a lot of work goes into creating an atmosphere, but sometimes I think those in the know can forget that they are designing for outsiders. Crissy Field was formed into the shape it is not to resemble a paisley, but to evoke both the air strip & the race track it once was, but is there any information on site letting the casual observer know this? I thought about that during dinner. While the name, the decor, & the staff outfits all evoked a military base that you might see in a movie, with dapper officers & women in crisp uniforms, the menu seemed to not match.

Take the pork albondigas. I don't know why one restaurant would call them pork albondigas & another pork meatballs & yet another would call them pork albondigas but follow it with a dash or parentheses & explain that they are pork meatballs in a delicate sauce that simply bursts with flavor. They were fantastic but I had to ask what they were when I was reading the menu, as did the couple next to us. I didn't grow up eating out a lot, but I've lived in four countries & hadn't seen the term before. I'm not shy, I'll ask, but I still feel for those who might be too shy to ask. What does mystery add to a menu? Maybe some day I'll find out. Certainly a menu that is too wordy is no good either. This menu was a good list. Not too long, not too short, easy to find something for your paleo meat-eating friend & probably for your vegan friend as well, but I while I saw great vegetarian options I didn't look for vegan menu items as I try not to eat out with vegans, & so really didn't care.

Back to the part of the menu I do care about: meat! The charcuterie was curiously named as well, in that it had no name, just a list of what was on the board. I know I can order a dish by the main ingredient, if there are not similar dishes on the menu, & I'll often shorten a wordy menu entry, but honestly didn't know how to describe the "fermin iberico sausage, aged manchego, cana de cabra, joyce's homemade membrillo" as anything other than a charcuterie, so it was odd that it wasn't named. (Is it a faux pas to have a Spanish inspired menu with French words? Ce lest vie.) Meat & cheese plate, please. I guess I do prefer simple names. The Presidio of San Francisco has strong Spanish roots & I can see that reflected in the menu, but I guess the Spanish names without explanations felt like a barrier to me. Maybe it was meant to feel like a US military base in another country. I can dig that; I know I need to learn more Spanish.

The bar featured some of my favorites, including 209 & Old Potrero. The cocktails were really tasty, & met in a good place between not boring but not containing 18 ingredients either. The food was just right. The service has a few places where the dust will settle off... everyone was friendly without being too eager, but there's just some ways where you can tell it'll get better with time. We found a seat right away on a Saturday, which was lucky for us & too bad for them & I hope they'll both fill up soon & that they'll stay open later. Is this the sleepy corner of San Francisco? Maybe for now but hopefully not for long.

The space is acoustically bright which worked to fill the room with sound when it was light on guests. I never had trouble hearing the staff or my companion. If there was music I don't remember it, which is good in my book. There are items for sale, as befits an actual commissary, but it was unclear when I'd want to wander over to go look closer. (And these days, I need a lot of closer or a lot of lighting to see the details.)

My partner & I split a few appetizers & several drinks, & I'd like to return for a full meal. The lamb shoulder is still calling to me. Post-meal coffee was Equator, which I hadn't had before (there, I've just outed myself as Not A Hipster) & I enjoyed it tremendously. Really, the whole evening was delightful, & I'd like to go back with more people, more time & more appetite. 

Finally, in an attempt to offend even the last reader who made their way to this end, I would encourage The Commissary to take advantage of being on Federal land & thumb their noses at California's foie gras ban. I'll be there weekly when you do.
author: noemi r.

description: Had the open faced mushroom and arugula sandwich. Very delish. Asked to sit by kitchen so we could watch them prepare the food. This restaurant is new but the area is a wonderful got walking. They have good coffee and desert options if you are interested as well. Great lunch for a business meeting.
author: Jessica M.

description:
The space is beautiful. The menu for both wine and food was overly complex. We had to ask so many questions of our waitperson that the three of us and she were
exhausted by the time we placed our order. These difficulties could be fixed but I would not go there until they are.
author: Lucille S.

description:
Not good.  Our experience was frustrating to say the least.  We made reservations for a birthday dinner several weeks ago.  The Commissary phoned to to tell us that needed to move our reservation to another day.  They had to accommodate a private party.   Okay, we were flexible.  After several tries and 25 minutes on hold to move to another date and time we got it.
Our reservation was for 7.  We arrived and table was set for 6.   We ordered cocktails and waited 20 minutes.  The order was wrong for a couple of us.  Another 20 minutes.  Our server did not seem to know a lot about the bar and liquor that was stocked.
We ordered tapas dishes.  the food arrived in a scattered sequence and short some of our items.   We had no silverware or plates.  So we waited for that.  We waited for the order to be corrected.  And waited.  Our entrees were brought out.  They were nice but nothing remarkable.  We waited to order dessert.  Our birthday guest was now tired.  We finally ordered ate our chocolate cookie with olive oil ice cream.  Nice.  Then the $408. bill came and we each put our credit cards in to share cost.  One guest was charged $408 on his card and the rest of us were charged $100.  So for a mere $708.  we had an experience we could NEVER recommend to anyone.  Ever.  Hopefully the credit card mishap can be remedied in a few minutes rather than 25 min on hold....
author: laura y.

description: Sat outside with my tiny dog for dinner at around 6pm.  It was windy and very cold.  There were no heaters but the staff kindly provided a blanket.  While outside we could see the beautiful interior and warm cozy atmosphere with crispy white linen.  Outside it was freezing on a wooden table.  The food was great but it just makes me crazy that I paid the same price as the interior even though they offered nothing to compare.  If offering outside dining at least go one step above camping!! Thoughtless
author: David A.

description: I have been here twice and thought it was truly amazing. Interesting flavors and much care given to each dish. We sat at the counter and watched the kitchen action. The most amazing was how friendly the staff was. Everyone smiled and the second time we came they remembered us and introduced themselves. Wow! It is our new favorite place to eat
author: J J.

description: Just reviewing to say their Octopus starter dish is the tenderest, tastiest Octopus I've ever had...pea and ham croquets were lovely...no one in our party liked the pork meatballs....... and our waiter was a  great guy, friendly and knowledgable and very patient with a certain person's indecisiveness......alcohol drinks could be more generous portions though for what they cost.....the hostess was hot and efficient...:)
author: Michael G.

description:
We made a reservation for two via yelp with great ease! We sat at the chefs table which was awesome, highly recommended it! 
The place was pretty full for a Monday. The location is awesome and I liked how airy and  open the restaurant was. They had a secluded room for a private party and a welcoming seating area once you go inside. Very different eating space from what I have experienced before. 
Food: 
We tried a variety of things, roasted pardon peppers, ham and pea croquettas, avocado salad,roasted Romano beans, braised greens, chorizo and clams,corn, cuttlefish and the steak. 
Every thing we had was perfectly seasoned and executed. The Romano beans, corn, chorizo and clams, and cuttlefish dishes are a must try! 
We did not care for the roasted peppers since they actually were not padron peppers but shishito peppers and the braised greens. 
We were not rushed and enjoyed our date even though we had really close neighbors as we were sitting at the chefs table. 
Service could have been a notch better, our waters were empty a few times and I was unsure if the water on the table was a community water or for my neighbors. I also got the impression that the server was a bit unfamiliar with the wines. But our server was friendly. 
Drinks were tasty but definitely on the small size, which I don't mind if I get a little buzz. ( I didn't) The wine by the glass is served in what looks like recycled wine bottle bottoms. 
Overall we had a great experience, would have given five stars had the service been a tad bit better. I will be visiting again!
For dessert we had the arroz con leche and the bittersweet chocolate bar. Both hit the spot in our overstuffed bellies. 
It was an expensive dinner but I felt it was worth every penny especially since I was able to see my dinner being made by the chefs who were also very friendly and maintained a clean working station the whole time.
author: Debbie M.

description: Wanted to love it-I didn't. The dining room is lovely, the tables well spaced and the chairs are comfortable. After reading great reviews I wanted to love it-I didn't. The selections of vodka from what appeared to be a full bar were disappointing. The wait staff although very nice was surprisingly awkward. Perhaps we had someone in training. The ingredients were very fresh and the vegetables were well prepared-not overcooked but our entrees had way too much salt. We didn't try the desserts so I can't comment. The food just didn't live up to the surroundings especially for the prices they charge
author: Rose G.

description: Excellent and welcoming service, warm ambience, outstanding presentation of food.  The location is excellent - in the classic brick barracks buildings overlooking the parade ground of the Presidio.  The presentation of the food was outstanding - works of art.  The cauliflower soup was exquisite and I'm looking forward to having it again; the presentation of the hamburger was excellent and it tasted good - but the patty certainly was not worth the $14 cost - disappointing in quality.  The cappucino was adequate, but nothing to write home about.  Staff was excellent, welcoming, and made the dining experience a pleasure.
author: Wolf B.

description:
Overall had a great experience.  The location is in a restored red brick Presidio building at the Main Post, an historic location dating back to the earliest city beginnings in 1776. The front windows look out onto the Main Parade Ground.  Parking is readily available.

The interior is spacious, with high ceilings, and with a flexible arrangement of tables, from 2-person tables, to community tables to bar seating. There is generous space between the table allowing a lot of privacy.

We arrived on-time for a 5:30 reservation, having just visited the Walt Disney Family Museum a few buildings down the hill, and were seated promptly without any waiting.  Service during the meal was attentive and friendly. Between courses the table was discretely cleaned and utensils set.

We shared 3 small plates: salt cod fritters, albondigas and  the octopus, potatoes, olives, and pimeton.  The octopus and potatoes were a tasty combination. We also shared a striped bass with clams entree. The broth was well flavored. We ordered bread late in the meal to use with the tasty broth. Recommend asking for bread earlier in the meal.  Had the JL Bonnacorsi and Bengoetxe wines by the glass. Food presentation was excellent.
author: David E.

description: Have tried this place twice. Not returning. This is one of those places that seem to be proliferating lately, for some unfathomable reason, where they believe heavily salting all their dishes is a really great idea. Note to the restaurant: salt is definitely a stupid thing to go overboard with. Get over your salt fixation and maybe I'll be back.
author: Jerph H.

description: Cauliflower soup,  salads and open-faced sandwich were better than we expected - in fact, yummy.  The menu is small, and we usually share dishes, including desserts -- three of us usually ordering 3 or 4.  There were only two - but they were great, one chocolate and one creamy, pudding like with a "frosted" piece of banana -- terrific.  We did not know they took reservations, and they could not have been nicer -- seating us at a slightly larger table to accommodate us.  We loved everything and found the service friendly and good.  The setting is iconic, and we reflected again on how lucky SF is to have the Presidio's legacy.  p.s.  Liked it that they offer some "to go" items already packaged, too.
author: Sharon H.

description: Had a wonderful time!  The staff was entertaining and made us feel right at home.  Our waiter made suggestions of what to order, and we were so glad he did!  We weren't as impressed with the entrée choices, so we went with several appetizer options.  The brussel sprouts, octopus (so tender), little gem salad with fried anchovy bits, and the desserts of sorbet/pumpkin flan were the highlights.  Definitely a must try for cocktails, apps and dessert!
author: S T.

description:
We had a great early dinner at the Commissary the other night.  I'm generally not a big fan of Spanish cuisine/tapas, but I really enjoyed the food.  Our favorite thing was the heavenly gazpacho - liked it so much we ordered two to go!  The other items we had were also very good, including the two deserts.  Everything was tasty, fresh, well portioned and priced. 
Contrary to some other reviewers, we experienced great service, starting with the hearty welcome from Malcolm when we arrived, which set the stage for the evening.  We were happily seated in the far corner at the kitchen counter (a wonderfully entertaining seating option).  Because we were a bit out of the way, we had to wave someone down a couple of times when we needed something "off cycle", but it was no big deal.  Our server and his "assistants" did a great job of getting things to us quickly.  They seemed a touch understaffed (especially by the time we left around 7:30pm), but were working efficiently and were very knowledgeable and friendly.     
As many have said, this is not a good option for a quiet and/or formal date.  It's a boisterous, open, casual atmosphere with largely communal tables and counters.  I don't think there's anything wrong with it - just something to know before you go.   
My only critiques are towards the drinks.  The cocktails are very small for the price, and I don't like the glassware for the wine.  Call me old fashioned but I don't want to drink wine out of something that seems like a finger bowl :)
We will definitely be back!
author: Ellen H.

description: Beautiful new restaurant in the Presidio. Went there last night for a glass of wine and some snacks with friends. We were able to get seats at the bar.  The wine/drink selection was good.  We shared a few items, which were all tasty, especially the octopus.  Will need to return for a full dinner.
author: Dilly M.

description: The food is amazing. Updating my original review as we tried it one more time at a friend's request.  Service was much better than before.  Sit in the "kitchen" area if you get the chance.
author: Bryson S.

description: Wonderful ambiance and decor, great staff- so welcoming, knowledgeable and game for some fun. My dinner partner and I dined in the back room area, in the kitchen quarters and got to observe a bunch of the firing and plating of everyone's dinners as well as the pastry chef assembling desserts. We had a wonderful meal and I would recommend the corn on the cob and the padron peppers in particular. Very delicious and beautifully presented.
author: Jessica P.

description: The Commissary in the Presidio is the go-to restaurant for special events!! Great location with lots of parking.  Last Saturday we celebrated our son's 30th birthday dinner party there.   I was a little nervous because I wanted everything to go right. To my delight, it was expertly managed with great service from their warm and courteous service staff.   From the moment we were served drinks and appetizers outside on the veranda to the special serving of the "out of this world" abalone sashimi prepared to absolute perfection (special permission was granted for the chef to prepare and serve the abalone that was previously caught by our son) by the chefs at The Commissary to the beautifully prepared entrees and sides that showed great care appealing to our eyes and other senses, we knew this was something very special.  Our family and guests were totally enraptured and impressed from start to finish.  We had brought our own dessert, a round 12 inch St.Honore cake, that the staff showed great care first to place the birthday candles then waiting for the singing the birthday song and blowing out the candles to finish to take the cake back to cut and serve each pieces of cake with its own puff pastry filled with custard!  Totally amazing experience with their delicious meat entrees with Spanish influence to their excellent service!!   I especially loved the strip steak cooked to medium rare perfection!  Kudos to the chef and staff of The Commissary!  Those of us who chose the stone fruit salad, let's just say, we were a little silent for awhile with smiles on our faces....We will definitely be back to enjoy the food and the beautiful experience unique to The Commissary!!
author: Susan H.

description: Ok... I have to be honest. I came in just for a double latte. That's what I got. I took one sip and said,"OMG!" I have had Coffee all over the world and I have to say this was the best double latte I have ever had. I recommend trying it. I love that it was a short and not overwhelmed with milk and the flavor, wow, I couldn't stop talking about it. The service is cool. Paula who served me was super sweet and amicable. I'll be by on Monday for another latte.
author: Mary M.

description: Great addition to the Presidio. Many community tables - so a nice way to meet new people. Unique style of cocktails.
author: Vicki L.

description: Had a great time seated at the bar watching the chefs cook.  Definitely get the corn! The tuna basquaise was also tasty. Beautiful area to stroll around after dinner.
author: Jeanna H.

description: Went with a couple of friends to try out Tracy Dejardin's new restaurant.  I hate to say it but we were all disappointed.  The space is beautiful, being there in the Presidio, the building was cool and we liked what they did with it.  The service was also good, however, the food was not very impressive.  We all love spanish food, and tried to choose our courses so we could try as many menu items as possible.  Overall, nothing really was very memorable.  We are hoping it is just because the restaurant is still newish and finding its footing.  Will give it another shot in a couple of months.
author: Lori H.

description: We tried a lot of items on the menu and all were very good. Service was both attentive and friendly. Nicely designed space, warm and the tables are set far enough apart so  there's no sense of intrusion of other diners.
author: Howard C.

description: Delicious food, very good service, nice ambience, easy parking. Order tapas and wine then go for the big plates. Memorable dishes were the octopus, steak, chicken, squid, granitas.  Prices were very reasonable. Fun night in a great new restaurant. Highly recommended. We even saw top chef Traci De Jardins.
author: Mario S.

description: I was born on the base . This wonderful restaurant is on the site that used to be the U.S. Army band in this building and now one of the greatest restaurants in San Francisco. Great food great location incredible staff. It also appears that they must have more than one artist  on staff because their wine list is fantastic
author: George L.

description:
There were four of us and we all really enjoyed our dishes. Plus, all the sides were excellent. The only reason I hesitate to give four stars is the noise level--not as bad as Arguello, but very loud, nonetheless.

Excellent service and yes, we would return.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Late lunch 2:00PM Tuesday of Thanksgiving week, so dining room was only half empty and service was good.  The space is wonderful - lots of light streaming through windows, tall windows, great historic feel.  In addition to the dining room, there is counter and table seating in the kitchen which is fun.

However, the food did not live up to the space.  The burger was excellent - perfectly cooked as ordered, and flavor of piquillo tapenade made it one of the best we've had.  But the other entree was awful - an open-faced sandwich of mushrooms, grilled onions, a few carrot coins with some sort of tangy ?goat cheese? sauce (can't find it on the online menu).  The chopped mushrooms - king trumpets, according to the server - were slimy and tasteless, and the rest of the ingredients were uninteresting and just greasy.  I expected an interesting interplay of flavors.

Coffee was good, but snickerdoodle cookie was gooey-undercooked in the middle.  Couldn't eat anything but the edges.

Very surprising for a Traci des Jardins restaurant.
author: L. D.

description: Very fun to sit at the counter of the large open kitchen to watch the chefs make magic. One of our favorite restaurants now--menu seems rather limited but it's tapas style so you can order several things. AMAZING signature chicken dish, flavorful Spanish-style shrimp, loved the stone fruit/arugula salad, filet to die for. super easy to get to (in the Presidio) and lots of free parking right outside. (in this city, that's a huge advantage). No wonder Michael Bauer says it's one of the 100 best in the Bay Area. They'll give you tastes of the Spanish wines--I liked the Mencia. top notch, uber-friendly service (no longer open for lunch)
author: Karen M.

description:
Delicious!!

The standouts on the menu?  Roasted Chicken, Brentwood Corn and Peach Salad.  All of them were amazingly balanced, interesting and delicious!  I will definitely be back!

Oh, and parking is abundant and easy and we walked around the parade grounds after dinner.  It was lovely.
author: Mary G.

description: I'm so bad about writing reviews but I seriously had to after dinner here...the food was sooo good. Our server was amazing (and I'm the asshole that forgot her name). We sat at the Chef's table and I wasn't totally sure how I would feel about that, since I'm more of a table kind of girl and seriously a sucker for a comfy booth, but it was a really cool experience and was helpful in the ordering process as well. We started with the salt cod fritters, if you love fried and you love salt, you will love these. Lucky for me, I do, so I was good to go. We also got the crispy new potatoes, super yummy sauce in case you were wondering, and the cauliflower soup which was good but if you're debating between that and something else, go with that other thing. After that, we were pretty much full but zero chance of not ordering more food so we fought over the chicken or the trout for a while, worked our appetites back up and went with the trout. Sidebar, I rarely order chicken at restaurants I'm excited about, but duuuuude it looked so good coming out of the kitchen. my pain in the ass friend was not on board, however. But in the trout's defense it was no joke. We loved it. We got the asparagus  as a side and you should too. Pretty much no way we could move on to dessert after that but we left full and happy...can't think of one negative to our night...
author: Tahla J.

description:
4 stars for food - 2 stars for service.

The cocktails are delicious, bartender could not have been more friendly and welcoming.  Our waiter was friendly but service quickly went downhill. 

Long wait between courses, dirty plates/silverware not cleared before a runner arrived with next course.  When table was cleared we received our entree and had to wait several minutes for any silverware with which to eat it.  Our waiter was no where to be seen and no one checked to see if we needed anything.  Literally could not see waiter on the floor for so long we thought he had gone home.

The food was spot on.  Pea/jamon croquetas were some of the best I've had (almost ordered a second) and the smoked octopus was intriguing.  A perfect Gazpacho and delightful and perfectly cooked roast chicken, beautifully presented.  The chocolate souffle cake with saffron ice cream was a perfect finish.

Would come back for the food but expect better service at this price
point.  I've had better @ Denny's!
author: Susan B.

description: I really wanted to like this restaurant. The location is a lovely spot. The service was good. But one does go to a restaurant for the food. Two of us went for dinner. We ordered 3 dishes including the steak which was the highest priced entree. The meat was tough and tasteless. The rest of the dishes were nothing to speak of at all. A small lamb pattie with some sauce--$17-$18. Amazing the high prices and the the number of people who go there. They must be either tourists or there first time there. I cannot see this eatery will last.
author: Janet l.

description: Great folks and interesting old Presidio ambiance. Small tasty plates and very good waiter with very suggestions. Enjoyed all dishes although with those appetizer peppers we left 1/2 because of growing heat as we munched. Very pleasant Spanish wine list. Will be back despite a pretty high la quenta for 2!
author: Bill D.

description: Great space, delicious food, friendly service...we really enjoyed our experience at the Commissary. Honestly, from start to finish, there wasn't a dish that I wouldn't be happy to have again. The pork ribs, the octopus, the halibut, the ice cream sandwich! The roja sangria was also very good, with the right amount of fruit and the appropriate level of sweetness for our taste. I'll look forward to going back!
author: Kendall G.

description: I was so excited to get a reso to celebrate an early father's day with my parents! We ended up being early for our reso by over an hour. We planned to grab some apps and wine at the bar until our reso time. The hostess quickly accommodated us and sat us at a table early! So amazing!  We got comfortable, looked over the menu and were chatting and realized after almost 15 mins, we had never seen our server. Luckily the busser noticed and welcomed us and explained the menu a bit and got our server for us. She was awful,  from start to finish. But luckily the bar manager went ABOVE AND BEYOND!  Alex is a true gentleman and exudes quality customer service. He made great recommendations for wine and helped guide us thru the wine list,  the menu and picked amazing desserts to end with. The food is absolutely exceptional with a beautiful,  chic yet casual atmosphere. Our experience with EVERYONE in the restaurant was phenomenal, except our server, she never even brought us back our left overs. I cannot wait to go back, but if I am sat in her section, I will asked to be moved. All in all, she did not ruin my experience or my father's, but she put a bit of a damper on the evening.
author: Charese E.

description: I am surprised with the rating here. To me I thought the restaurant was superb. Being able to sit with my fiancé around the open kitchen was an amazing experience! You watch them cook your meal in front of you. Great food, I had the steak and thought it was cooked perfectly. The staff here is truly genuine, credit that to the chef.
author: Rob B.

description: very fun new restaurant.  Service was very respectful, we were able to talk and enjoy ourselves without  the push of a waiter.  Food is very good, creative, and the atmosphere is warm and open.
author: Milton R.

description:
The food was really good and it is one of the few new restaurants in the city where you can actually hear what your dinner companionas are saying. Service, however, was beyond anything I have experienced in a restaurant of this caliber.. My three dinner mates receievd their dishes(including my husband who ordered the same main) and I am just sitting there.. ten minutes go by and nothing.. Waiter never came by to follow up so he was unaware I was sitting there with nothing in front of me.. Had to practically trip a bus person to get someone's attention My food arrived about 20 minutes after everyone else's.. they were finishing. Other side dishes arrived cold. 
 The manager stepped right up to the problem and was very gracious.. That and the quality of the food will have me coming back.. Cuttlefish and lamb dishes ...yum!
author: Audrey B.

description:
Fresh, innovative feel.  Staff dedicated, extremely friendly and invested in this new adventure.
Main dining room needs some noise-absorbing materials.  Good specialty cocktails.
Menu entrees could use some improvement.  Delicious peaches.  We live in the Presidio, so hope this to be our version of "Cheers."  Paula S.
author: Paula S.

description:
-some excellent food ,like the halibut & the ice cream sammie.
quite  surprisingly the plain roast potatoes with a romesco like sauce was amazing. the saffron blondie was strange.
the service was extremely  amateurish 
 - water was spilled. i asked a server to ID the cheeses on the platter - he couldnt do it.    we had to ask for water several times.  many people milling about, not organized - main problem  - no one seemed to be in charge.
-the other major problem was atmo- the lighting was dim not in a cool flattering  way but in a dark depressing  way.  the communal tables are a mistake - sitting at one with a few people is sad.
for these prices, these add up to big mistakes.
author: Kim Y.

description:
I was greatly disappointed by this experience. The front of the house felt like no one  was in charge. The table at which we were eventually seated was available when we arrived, but we were left to hover at the too small bar where we were unable to get our hands on a drink menu, much less a drink. There seemed to be plenty of staff, but not much happening.

The ambiance of the restaurant is a bit lacking- cool wood tables and light fixtures, but bare white wall and very loud- just kind of blah.

Our group of four was seated at a table designed for 6 or 8. We arranged ourselves on two sides so we didn't have to yell across the table, which was still awkward. Then the service was SLOW. And disorganized. We ordered a few tapas style starters, which did not come, and did not come...... We then decided to order our dinner to try to get a jump on it since the kitchen seemed to be working at a glacial pace. Then a runner arrived with what we hoped were our starters, but it was two side dishes that we had not ordered. An inquiry was sent back to the kitchen about the status of our starters. Two of three eventually arrived - salt cod fritters that were very good and a mediocre croquetta. Laster, we finally got the potatoes brava, which were delicious and the best thing we ate all night. Given the inordinate time for the order- they comped the potatoes.  The potatoes were so good that we ordered a second order which, unfortunately, when they arrived were so salty that they were inedible.

At one point in the evening a chef came out and wandered around the restaurant with a confused look on his face. We thought he might stop to chat with a table or two, but he just wandered and then disappeared again. 

All drink refills took ages. They eventually comped us two glasses of wine due to the slow and confused service. We ordered the chicken as an entree per the recommendation of our waiter (who was so attractive that he was the highlight of the dining experience), only to be told minutes later that they were sold out. We ordered the steak which was supposed to be a New York strip - but it was not a strip steak and was so tough and flavorless that it was barely edible, and accompanied by some unseasoned broccolini and undercooked potatoes. The rest of the dishes were fine, but nothing special. 

Given the price point, the food, service and ambience,  this Traci des Jardins restaurant was a disappointment.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Wow!  The food is amazing, atmoshere is relaxed, and the decor is open and in good taste.  
We were seated in  the kitchen, overlooking the food preparation area.  It was like watching The Food Network, and we were entertained and engaged.  The cooking staff interacts with the guests in a light and friendly manner.
We enjoyed small plates as our appetizer, an amazing mushroom salad, and shared the yummy chicken and almond cake dessert.
We are looking forward to a return visit, and will bring friends to share this positive experience with the next time....and SOON!
Thank you.
author: D N.

description: One of the few restaurants where everything that came to our table was perfection!  I highly recommend the salt cod fitters and the roasted chicken.  Although our table also shared the octopus, steak, and halibut which were all exceptional.  For dessert I had the lemon ricotta fritters which were a total home run.  The service was outstanding.  Definitely going back and I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Ray Z.

description: We waited an hour for a table. The manager was less than helpful and ended up turning rude when he knew we were going to write a yelp review. We ended up leaving going to another restaurant. The chef and owners deserve a better front of house manager
author: Steven M.

description: We had a reservation at 7pm and when we arrived were told that it would be a few minutes before our table would be ready.  The bar was fulll so we ordered drinks in the entry seating area.  We inquired several times about our table and were told each time that it would be a few minutes.  We were not seated until 8pm by the manager and he did not apologize for the wait.  The waitperson was nice and efficient but management doesn't seem to care about treating guests with consideration and courtesy.
author: Kathryn P.

description: I was excited to finally check out this place with my husband for lunch - I love the Presidio Social Club and was hoping for another great place within the Presidio. We wound up sitting at the bar, which is something we often prefer anyway. The lunch menu is pretty small - some kind of cheese board, 2 different salads, a mushroom soup, and a burger. I love a good burger, so we both opted for that. The burger comes with a simple arugula salad, which was good. The burger was disappointing. We both ordered "medium" burgers and they both came well done. We would have said something, but the patties were so thin (they had to have been the frozen kind) I don't know how you would have cooked them. Even forgiving the well doneness, it just had no flavor or juiciness. The saving grace was a nice olive tapenade on the burger. It was $14. I don't mind paying $14 for a burger, but this was not at all worth it. The venue itself is nice - next time, I'll just go for a drink.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
Let me start by saying that the food and drinks are 5 star!  Only a few flaws drop it a star (I'm a tough critic) - but I would return in a flash.

Cocktails were terrific as was the house sangria - a red that wasn't too sweet and perfectly complemented our entrees.  We loved the food - particularly the octopus, the ribs and the blistered local peppers.  Portions were more generous than expected - no complaints!  For entrees we shared the chicken.  Roast chicken is not an adequate description - it was perfectly cooked - even the thick breast meat was moist - and the accompaniments were terrific (including the liver mousse and the medjool dates that provided a sweetness complementing the richness of the mousse).  We also loved the halibut dish which included perfectly cooked prawns (not at all overcooked so these weren't just sitting waiting to be served) and the dusting of spicy chorizo corteza on the fish gave it a spicy kick without overwhelming the fish or the lovely beans and sweet roasted tomatoes on the plate.  We also ended on a high note with a fabulous ice cream sandwich (olive oil ice cream and the chocolate cookie were a great match).  

The service was generally very attentive, but unfortunately our server forgot our order of grilled sweet corn (we had so much food we didn't follow up), we weren't even asked if we wanted water (we did and had to flag someone down to get it), and our coffee was tepid (despite being poured fresh).  Drinks are custom made but getting the drinks from the bar to the table took more time than I expected given the fact the restaurant wasn't filled and the bar area was also not very busy.  However, our server was helpful in her suggestions about what to order and how to enjoy the meal, and the coffee wasn't charged to us.  

All in all, this is a lovely spot in the Presidio with fantastic food - strong flavors, authentic Spanish style and a welcome addition to the San Francisco restaurant community with its overweighted inspiration from the Mediterranean (in general), Italy (in particular) and Asia.
author: Bonnie L.

description: I totally agree with the many superlatives expressed in the review of others.  All 3  of us  gave our lunch choices a High 5.  Delicious. The  decision makers there are smart in not having a bloated menu, one so overly ambitious that it falls short.  There is of course the historical vibe - I have dined at 3 other places on the Presidio property, and this being prime real estate with fantastic views, I am once again reminded of how great it is living near San Francisco.  The young woman who was our wait staff member was helpful, not cloying, with good humor.  Service was perfect.  I would definitely recommend to others and will return soon.
author: LaVonne F.

description: Underwhelmed is the word that sums up our experience here.  We had their Valentine's Day three course meal. for $70 we expected much better food and services. The portions are small, uneven in saltiness, parts are greasy.  The first course quail was good but greasy. The second course beef cheek was just okay, also greasy, especially the veggies. The desserts was the weakest course. Both our dessert, cake and pudding have very little flavor. The services was spotty, even though the desserts were pre-ordered as part of the 3 course meal it took them about 40 minutes to get the desserts on our table after we finished the 2nd course. They seem to use very fresh ingredients with interesting combination for all their dishes but the result were just okay. Nothing that would make you say wow.  For the price they are charging there should've been some wows. Sadly the only wow we got was the view outside the restaurant with the sun going down behind the Golden Gate Bridge which was free.
author: W J.

description: Had some amazing appetizers and wine there last night. Tasted very authentic, not 'Americanized'. Staff was attentive and friendly. Definitely coming back.
author: carolyn a.

description: This is a far cry from Jardiniere. It is a nice, cozy spot, but the service is horrible and the food is mediocre. I dined at the bar. Had to ask for water, utensils and a napkin. After 30 minutes, I had to ask about my salad course. It finally arrived and was a bunch of oversized, dry leaves. The main course was a mediocre New York strip that was not even close to the strip at Brazenhead or Bobo's.  The wines are served in stemless glasses that are supposed to be some sort of retro "commissary theme." If you want a bath on the way out, then you will enjoy being sprayed by the Presidio sprinklers next to your car.
author: Rick R.

description: Wow.  Not a good wow.  A very disappointed "wow".  Went for lunch yesterday.  Small uninspired menu; sweet but completely untrained server; the "charred rosemary vinaigrette" was just olive oil and salt - when we asked our server about that, she checked with the kitchen and was told "we forgot to make that today".  We've eaten at Traci des Jardin's restaurants in the past and were always pleased.  It's a little past time to be working out the kinks in this new restaurant.  Maybe they should stick to dinner.  I hope that's a better experience, though I won't be trying it.  Bad experience all the way around.
author: Sue S.

description: Food was good.....but the service is not equal to the prices. You expect someone approaching the table a few times ...but I guess they assume once you have your order thats all there is! Can wait to return.
author: Sharon M.

description: Our party of 5 enjoyed the food, though the vegetarian in our group was not impressed by the chickpea pancake main course.  The service was atrocious for this caliber of a restaurant.  Drinks took forever, courses arrived on top of each other, drink glasses not cleared and we waited forever for dessert.  There was a very hectic, disorganized feel to the service.  Bartenders and wait people were seen bickering over tabs and a beer question was answered by wait person saying that they did not drink beer so couldn't speak to the question. The main host overseeing the room seem completely uninterested in what was going on and the service really detracted from the whole meal.  The food was very good but I can't believe the service was so poor.
author: Alice B.

description: I really wanted to like this place. We went with another couple and first impression of the decor was bland, people were eating their dinner on a Saturday night in sports clothes (which is fine and typical in SF for brunch or at Blue Barn for a salad but not so much at a $$$ restaurant on the weekend for dinner), and the waiter had zero personality. Service was slow, food was small portions for the price (we love gourmet / high quality dinning but this wasn't worth it), meatballs dry, potatoes boring, peppers needed more sea salt and to be charred / seared more, tuna was nice but small, deserts tiny (chocolate bar too rich - needed something to break it up like a light cream of sorts, and olive oil cake a non-event). The toilet has a broken tap and the lights were super bright. They couldn't get the lighting in the restaurant right (you could see them turning it up and down every 15 minutes which disrupted the ambience), they needed candles on the table or something to add charm. My husband didn't like the cod fritter appetizer. The corn on the cod was really good! The swiss chard didn't float my boat and the music was Pandora. Ahhh well worth a try but would not recommend it to anyone and feel bad for the owners as they didn't manage to execute on the overall experience. We walked out the door and no one said thanks or said goodbye. Better off going to the Presidio Social Club for an iconic SF experience. Sorry guys, hate to slam you like this but this was our experience.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Unfortunately, not a pleasant experience. Serios downsides:
1. Impossible to find. No signage in Presidio and front signage is hardly visible. 
2. If you're one who doesn't drink/drive and prefer taxis, you might want to pass on this one, as taxis can't find it going there and won't come to pick you up afterwards.
3. Communal tables can be fun for lunch and for some for casual dinners. However, if with a date or friend, I'd like to be able to have some privacy to my conversation.
4. We were seated at a communal table with two other couples, both of whom had small children, who were misbehaving. We could have stayed home with our own noisy children!
4. Because of the communal tables, waiters come up behind patrons to take their order and we had to turn our heads/chairs around everytime he came up behind us to bring/discuss something. In most restaurants with regular tables, you can actually face your server and not have to twist your neck everytime he comes up behind you.
5. Service was terrible. When seated, server plopped down napkins, but forgot utensils. Had to flag him down for plates, wine refills, bill  and other requests. 
6. "Small plate" items were served in crocks that resembled pet food dishes. Rustic, but not exactly attractive!
Food
1. Most small plates were unattractive as ingredients just seemed mushed together with not thought to attractiveness of plating..
2. Cod cakes were dry and flavorless. Chicken and mushrooms just okay. 
3. Others at our table seemed equally unimpressed. 
4. For prices, it felt like dining in a cafeteria setting. Nothing on tables to ehance experience. Someone kept turning lights up/down, obviously trying to find right "ambiance"...there is none.
Suggestions:
1. Please provide some tables for parties of 2 and 4, so patrons can have privacy and not get neck strain turning around to talk with servers and have to sit with children or noisy, unpleasant stranger tablemates..
2. Bars and high backless stools are fine for drinks/barfood, but not comfortable for an entire evening. 
Would like to see this succeed and I'm sure it will as it's the only game in the Presidio. But, for longevity, please consider the above suggestions. Thanks.
author: Elva E.

description: The location is spectacular but the food on the other hand is not so great. I had a burger and it was pretty good except that it was tiny and the fries were five extra dollars and they weren't even that good. Really? I also had the little gem salad which tasted good but was microscopic. The portions used to be bigger. They are trying to be too fancy and it's not working out to great. I do not recommend.
author: John D.

description: We were referred to the restaurant by the excellent concierge at the fabulous Inn at the Presidio, where we were staying (see separate review)... The service is welcoming and attentive... Almost the entire staff has recently turned over, and they're even better than before...  The menu, which changes daily, is always exciting...  My wife and I split a chicken dish, which was outstanding... The couple with us had the Dover Sole, which was very fresh, and delicious... Their wine list was quite impressive, as were their selections of desserts...  We will certainly be back with other neighbors, friends, and family
author: CDR JAY C. O.

description: Friendly and abysmally slow service. Expensive and tiny portions
author: Bob T.

description: Not terrible but way under expectations.  The burger was lousy.  The meat was about equal to a McDonald's single and was eclipsed by a HUGE bun, which was very moist on the outside (good) and very, very dry on the inside (bad).  the bun was so big you could not taste the meat so it was really an order of bread with a sauce and paper thin patty.  We ordered sangria for the table.  Not one of our party finished even one glass as it was watery and tasted like rubbing alcohol.  Whole place had the feel of someone trying to save money rather than excel.  Very small selection for lunch.
author: James A.

description: Went for lunch with my wife and really enjoyed the food. We had been reading all of the negative reviews but, since we only live a couple of miles away, decided to judge for ourselves ... So glad we did! There are still a few service kinks they are working through (hence the 4 vs. 5 stars) but we really liked all four of the dishes we ordered. The cauliflower soup, grilled mushroom medley, clams & white beans, and grilled Serrano ham sandwich were all excellent, and we eat out a lot in the City. Please get the expediter(s) to expedite a little better/faster/smoother and the wait staff to keep up with the hustling kitchen (we had front-row seats so we could easily see that the kitchen was getting plates out quite efficiently but there was a delay getting them out to the tables) ... you'll earn that extra star from me and a whole lot better reviews from others. Good luck!
author: Dave E.

description: This is one of the best meals I've ever had out, and as a native San Franciscan I've had a lifetime of top notch restaurant experiences. The food was so flavorful--layered, complex, distinctive, and bright. We had trout, sablefish, pork, and chicken dishes at our table--all lovely. We had the artisanal bread paired with pasture 42 olive oil. This olive oil makes what you buy in a store (no matter how expensive) seem rancid and harsh. So this is what real Spanish olive oil tastes like--mild, silky, pure. The service was great; attentive, engaged. The location is such a joy for us San Franciscans who have watched the transformation of the Presidio and care deeply about the National Park and our historic buildings and grounds. The attention to local, sustainable and seasonable sources on the menu is also appreciated.
author: Emily S.

description: Went to Commissary for the first time and we loved it.  The place was packed but service was awesome (thanks Jose).  Unlike most restaurants, there are a lot of tables for six which we loved.  We ordered all the tapas to start which were great, especially the peppers.  The peach and arugula salad was outstanding.  We felt the portions were very substantial for the main dishes.  Will be back.
author: Wanda G.

description:
My husband and I had dinner here last night and it was just ok. I love the setting - they've done a really nice job on the space and I enjoyed sitting at the bar watching the chefs prepare dinner. Dinner was good enough, but not all that memorable. The biggest issue, however, was the service. A few issues in this area:

- Our waiter disappeared for long stretches of time. It took probably 20 minutes for him to take our order. Our neighbors at the bar complained about the same issue.
- It felt like the waiter was padding his tip. We ordered 2 starters, 1 entree, and 1 side to share between the two of us, to which the waiter said "that's a really light meal" and urged us to get another item. I added another starter and it ended up being way too much food. By the time our entree came out we weren't that hungry and left half of the dish and more than half of the side of squash uneaten. When the bill came there was an extra drink on there and when we informed the waiter he was less than apologetic. Instead, he seemed disappointed that we noticed...
- We must have waited 20 minutes after our appetizers were cleared for the entree to come out. Since we were sitting at the bar we could watch what was happening and it seems that they batch prepare all of their dishes, so they waited until a few other people ordered the chicken before preparing ours. I'm sure this is standard in the restaurant industry but they haven't quite figured out how to time it right. 
- One final issue is that they charge for sparkling water (not bottled, but the kind that they make on-site). I wouldn't have an issue with this, except that they ask whether you want still or sparkling water before even handing you the menu, giving the impression that they are both offered free of charge, as is customary in many similar restaurants. It shows up in a carafe, so again, no indication that they will charge $4 for it. I would just appreciate a more upfront approach if this is the decision that they have made (for example, the menu clearly states that they charge for bread and olive oil). 

All in all, I enjoyed some of the dishes but not enough to make me want to come back.
author: Emily S.

description: I have been several times and loved it. So I took 2 friends new to it. Service was great and food great as usual but the evening was marred by being given the bum's rush by what appeared to be the General Manager.
